text: 'Charging families for each bag of rubbish they make seems like a good idea for the environment and money. But it might not be. In many places, people put their rubbish in bags or bins, and a special truck takes it away. This service is usually free because people pay for it with local taxes. But families that make a lot of rubbish pay the same as those that make a little. More rubbish means more trucks and workers are needed, and this costs money. If throwing away rubbish is free, people will make too much rubbish. A simple solution is to make people pay for each bag of rubbish. This way, they might throw away less and recycle more. But two American economists, Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman, found that this idea does not always work well. They studied some American towns that started charging for rubbish. People had to buy stickers for their rubbish bags. Only bags with stickers were taken away. In Charlottesville, Virginia, people paid 80 cents for each bag. The number of bags went down by 37%, but people just put more rubbish in each bag. The weight of rubbish went down by only 14%. In other towns without this system, rubbish went down by 3.5% anyway. Some people also dumped rubbish illegally to avoid paying. Recycling went up by 15%, but many people were already recycling. In another study, the economists found that higher sticker prices only reduced rubbish a little. A 10% price increase cut rubbish by just 0.3%. People would need to buy less of everything to make a big change. Other things like income and education might also affect how much rubbish people make. Richer towns throw away more rubbish and have less time to recycle. Charging for rubbish is not a bad idea, but it is complicated. Simple ideas can have complex results, and sometimes they do not work as expected.'

Theodore Zeldin talks about how work might change in the future. Do you feel respected and appreciated at work? Just having a successful career is not enough anymore. Many people feel their jobs are not valued or understood. Even famous people can feel unhappy. Loving your job used to be special, but now you need to think about how your job affects you as a person. Does it make you happy? Does it help you grow? If your job makes you boring or too busy to learn new things, then money and status are not enough.
Zeldin wants to find out how work can help people feel fulfilled. Work should not just be about making money. It should help people discover new talents and meet different people. This change would not mean getting rid of unemployment. People want jobs that are interesting and make life better. Work should be like art, with happy people at the center.
Many jobs are not as good as they used to be. Doctors are stressed, accountants worry about ethics, architects can't be creative, and managers feel stuck. Companies are getting smaller, and employees do not feel connected to their work. In Britain, only 8% of workers feel their values match their company's values.
Zeldin is studying different jobs to see how they affect people. He wants to find better ways to work. Many experts focus on making companies last longer and earn more money, but we also need to think about what makes us happy as people. Are we really happy at work, or are we just working because we have no other choice?
For example, hotel workers often have low pay and long hours. Hotels could be more than just places to sleep. They could be cultural centers where people from different countries meet and learn from each other. Hotel staff could do more than just simple tasks. They could help guests connect with the city and each other. But accountants often say hotels should focus only on making money.
Zeldin believes work is about relationships. People want to be independent and choose their jobs and colleagues. They need to talk to people from different backgrounds. Good communication is important, but real conversation is even better. It helps people understand each other and feel equal. Every time we have a meaningful conversation, the world changes a little bit.

**Broadcasting: The Spread of a Technology**
Broadcasting first meant spreading seeds by hand. It is a way to think about growth and sharing. Broadcasting is about sending out information to many people. This idea started when new technology could send words and pictures electronically. 
Television is like the telegraph and telephone, which are two-way communication tools. But, from the start, TV was made to send information from one place to many homes. This fit well with how people lived in modern societies. 
There were some different ideas about how TV could work. In the 1930s, people in Britain tried to use TV like a telephone. Magazines showed how to make TV equipment at home. But big companies set rules that stopped these small experiments. 
In the USA and other countries, people watched TV in public places in the 1930s. This was before most people had TVs at home. But companies wanted to sell TVs for home use, so TV became something people watched at home. 
As people got more money, they could buy TVs and other things for entertainment at home. This happened in many Western countries and is now happening worldwide. 
Broadcasting helped governments share important information with everyone. It also helped create a sense of community in countries. Broadcasting was seen as a way to give everyone access to information and help them take part in society. 
Today, TV and broadcasting are changing. The way we think about broadcasting might change too. It might become just a way to talk about how we used to share information in the past.

**Clutter**  
Sometimes, it feels like no matter how many things you have, you never feel safe. It's normal to want a home that meets your needs, but sometimes wanting more things can get out of control. Modern ads make us feel like we need more to be happy. They tell us, "If you don't have this, you are not good enough." Try not to look at any ads next time you walk down the street. Ads are everywhereâ€”on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, shirts, and the internet. They all tell us to buy more and more.
**Caves**  
People all over the world study caves. They want to know how caves are made, how water moves in them, and what lives inside them. Caves are a small but interesting part of nature. They make us curious and we want to learn more about them. Many people study caves, both professionals and people who visit caves for fun. Studying caves can be hard because you need to be fit to go inside them.
**Weather Watch**  
A long time ago, people watched the weather with just their eyes. This helped start the study of weather, called meteorology. Today, we use satellites and computers to learn about the weather quickly. Weather science uses big words, but simple weather knowledge is still important. Human experience helps turn computer data into weather forecasts. People can still notice things about the weather that help scientists understand it better.

**Music and Theatre**
I used to think opera was mostly about theatre. But now I know that music is the most important part of opera. I come from the theatre world, where the actor and their words are the focus. In theatre, the actor and audience usually speak the same language. 
At music events, like concerts or operas, many people do not know much about music. Some might feel embarrassed about this, but most are amazed by the performers' skills. Watching a great musician is like watching athletes; we see they are doing something much better than we can.
Theatre audiences have different expectations. They might not understand an actor's skill and often think they could do it too. They are not always impressed by long speeches, but they do ask, "How do you learn all those lines?" 
Theatre and music audiences can be the same people, but they meet the performers differently. In theatre, they are more equal. Music could learn from theatre about this relationship. Music performances are full of emotion and can be like theatre. But music events often feel formal, with strict dress codes and respect for conductors and soloists. 
Sometimes, audiences clap at the wrong time, which can interrupt the music. But many people are working to make music more welcoming. For example, Jonathan Dove's opera "In Search of Angels" was performed in different places, and the audience was part of the show. 
I wish music had more of the excitement and risk that theatre can have. Sometimes, using new or unusual places for music can surprise both performers and audiences. It might not be comfortable, but it can be exciting. 
I love both theatre and music and want more people to enjoy them.

**Sand**  
I think sand is amazing because it can become things like glass and concrete. But I don't like sand on the beach. It is a problem for me. Sand blows in your face, gets in your food, and hides things like keys and coins. When you are wet, sand sticks to you and is hard to remove. But when you step on a towel or get in a car, sand falls off everywhere. For days, you find sand in your shoes and socks. Sand stays with you for a long time. I do not like sand.
**Lock and Key**  
People want their homes to be safe and private. Long ago, people used a big piece of wood to lock doors. Now, we have electronic locks with many combinations. But people still like using a key. Some companies tried using smart cards to open doors, but people did not like them at home. They want to use a real key. So, one company made an electronic lock that also uses a metal key.
**Modern Art**  
I was worried about visiting the new Tate Modern gallery because I do not understand modern art. I like some art, like furry things, neon lights, and big photos. I think art should talk to you, but it does not work for me. The new gallery helps visitors understand art better. They have labels that explain the art and what it means. This helps me understand the art more.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**
When books become movies, many things are changed or removed. This can be hard for the writer, but it can also help them see new things. When I worked on a movie script, I saw that I could take out a lot of talking and details from the book, but still show the same idea. This doesn't mean the book's words were not needed. It's about how each type of story, book or movie, needs different things to help people understand. In books, we often see the same character details or words like "he said" to help us know who is talking. In plays, which are mostly talking, sometimes the words don't tell us much, but they help show that people are talking to each other.
**Watching Movies**
When we watch movies, we can feel like we are in a different world. For a short time, we forget about real life. But when the movie ends, we come back to the real world. Some people used to think movies were just for fun and not real art. They liked watching movies but didn't think they were important like other art forms.
**The Film Studios**
The Leiper Film Company studios had many different buildings. It was hard to find your way around because everything looked the same. There were three main doors, but only one took you where you wanted to go. It was confusing for new people, but the people who worked there knew their way. The workers made movies that helped people forget their problems for a while.
**Film-makers**
Many people want to make movies. There are books and classes about how to write scripts and make films. Some people, like Robert Rodriguez, made movies with little money and became famous. He made his first big movie when he was young. In the past, movie makers took more time to learn their job. They worked on small projects before making big movies. Now, people often have to work on their own to make movies.

In those days, many council houses were on the west side of the city. They were small and not very nice, made of orange bricks or white stucco. In summer, a factory two miles away made the air smell bad, like sulphur. In the morning, you could see a paperboy holding his nose because of the smell.
I don't remember much from my early life. But I do remember sitting by a window and looking at the houses. I also remember faces I can't name, my mother ironing towels in a house that wasn't ours, and snow falling on a big mansion.
My mother was a small, often angry woman. I didn't understand why she was angry. She liked to be alone, even in a room full of people. She wanted everything to be proper and clean. She told me to 'behave proper,' which meant not going into neighbors' gardens and sitting quietly for a long time.
My mother had some friends. There was Mrs. Buddery, who liked the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who didn't talk much, and Mrs. Laband, who was more lively. They talked about things like bad weather and children who didn't behave.
Growing up in West Earlham was the same for everyone. Until you were five, you stayed at home. After your fifth birthday, you went to school. Some kids had a mother with a bike to take them to school. My mother let other kids take me.
I remember the summer holidays. Sometimes, I saw things outside West Earlham, like a man who told stories about the Merchant Navy and a charity event where a woman gave out lemonade. My mother didn't like the charity because she thought they just wanted money.
My mother didn't like politicians. She thought they were greedy. But she cared about my education. Sometimes, she took me to the Norwich Castle Museum. We looked at paintings, and she even made a joke once about a Roman soldier in a painting.

**Philadelphia Avenue**
I walked down Philadelphia Avenue. It was getting dark, and the air was wet and sticky. I felt like I was sneaking around. I knew this street well. My neighbors, the Matzes and the Pritchards, lived here. There was also Han Kieffer's grocery store and the houses of my first friends. I used to play here when I was a child. I remember the little paths in the cement where rainwater flowed. I would skate or ride my scooter over them.
As I walked, I noticed the houses changed. The porches were lower, and the yards were smaller. Over time, some houses became stores, and some stores became homes again. I wondered how people lived in these places now.
**Bachelor Fads**
Rick Gilbert lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. It has big doors and brick walls. He didn't want one big open space, so he used a large plastic sheet to make a hallway and hide his office. This way, the kitchen is in the middle, where he can cook for friends or make coffee for clients. He used light wood for the floors and mixed modern furniture with old pieces from his parents.
**Bruce Chatwin**
Bruce Chatwin was a writer who loved to travel. His first book, "In Patagonia," was very special. It was a travel book that felt like a story. Chatwin sometimes changed facts to make his stories more interesting. He believed that traveling could help us learn about the past.
**Swimming**
One summer, it rained a lot. I went swimming in the pool behind my house. The rain made bubbles on the water. I thought about swimming across Britain, following the rain to the sea. I wanted to explore and feel free. Swimming, like walking and cycling, helps us see the world in a new way. It lets us find places that are still wild and mysterious.

'CRYING Charles Darwin thought that crying did not have a clear purpose. He was probably wrong. Scientists now say crying is important for social reasons. Psychiatrist John Bowlby said crying helps mothers and children become close. Many people think children cry because they feel helpless. But why adults cry is harder to understand. The sound of crying is less important than seeing someone cry. In early human groups, crying might have helped people trust each other and feel connected. We can cry for other reasons too. We might cry to show we care about people who are treated unfairly. Sometimes we cry without wanting to, like when we hear beautiful music or speeches. We might cry during a sad movie, especially when we are with others. Crying seems to have a social purpose, but scientists are still studying it.'

**The Heat is On**
Global warming is making the Earth warmer. We know this, but we are not sure how much warmer it will get or how it will change our lives. A warmer Earth means the weather will change everywhere. This will affect plants, animals, water, and soil. Humans use these natural resources to grow food, build cities, and live. So, changes in these resources are important.
In the last 100 years, humans have put more gases into the air. These gases make the Earth warmer. Scientists think this is not natural and is because of pollution. They use computers to try to predict what will happen with the climate. These predictions are not perfect, but they help us understand what might happen.
Scientists think the Earth's temperature will go up by 1Â°C to 3.5Â°C by the year 2100. The sea level might rise by 15-95 cm. There might be more extreme weather like heatwaves, floods, and droughts. These changes can affect where plants and animals live and how we get food and water.
Some changes might be good. For example, in Australia, warmer temperatures have helped grow more wheat. But many changes might be bad. Less water might be available, especially in dry areas. Glaciers and ice might melt, affecting animals and people. The Arctic ice might melt completely, which could be dangerous.
The biggest problem might be rising sea levels. Warmer water takes up more space, and melting ice adds more water to the oceans. Many people live near the coast, so rising sea levels could cause flooding. Cities like London, New York, and Tokyo could have problems. Small islands might disappear, and people might have to leave their homes. This would be very difficult for them and for the countries that help them.

'Mission to Mars Wanted: a middle-aged, married couple for a 501-day trip to Mars and back. Applicants must be strong and healthy. This is the plan of millionaire Dennis Tito. He wants to send a spaceship to Mars on 5 January 2018. The spaceship will go 160 km above Mars. It will use Mars's gravity to come back to Earth without using more fuel. This is important because the next chance to go to Mars is in 2031. New technology is needed for this mission. If everything is ready in time, the spaceship might go. Even if it doesn't, the work will help future space missions.'

**Aesthetics**
Art is something we see in things like buildings, books, paintings, and statues. But sometimes, we forget that art is more than just these objects. Art is about what we feel and experience when we see or use these things. 
Some art is very famous and has been admired for a long time. This can make it hard for us to see it in new ways. When art becomes "classic," it can seem separate from the people and times that created it. This makes it hard to understand what the art really means.
Art should not be separate from everyday life. Just like mountains are part of the earth, art is part of our daily experiences. People who study art should help us see how art connects to our lives.
To understand art, we need to look at everyday things that make us happy, like movies, music, and comics. These are also forms of art, even if we don't always think of them that way. 
Many people think art only belongs in museums or galleries. But art is everywhere, in the things we enjoy every day. When we see art as part of our daily life, we can appreciate it more.

**Observing Lions**
People often think lions hunt in groups like a team. They imagine lions hiding and then jumping out to catch their food together. Lions seem to work well as a team to get their next meal. But after watching lions for many years, we see things differently. We started studying lions in 1978. We wanted to know why lions hunt together, take care of their babies, and scare other animals with loud roars. If animals work together, it should help them have more babies. But sometimes, helping others can be bad for one animal. So, why do lions work together? We thought we would find the answer in two or three years. But lions are very good at doing nothing. It took us a long time to learn about them. Lions can live up to 18 years, so we are only now finding answers to our questions.
**Pop Music Review**
Bedrock's third album was very important for the band. The album, called "New Life," changed rock music in the country. The old style of music was serious and loud. The new style was lighter and mixed different sounds. The album had funny and clever songs. Bedrock wrote songs about things like sunbathing and Sunday afternoons. The album's best songs were about deeper feelings. One song, "So Low," was about the weather. Another song, "To the Brink," was a serious ballad. "New Life" had 16 great songs with no bad ones. It was a very good album.
**Extract from an Autobiography**
As a child, I loved stories about "The Sibyl," wise women from the past. My mother told me a story about one Sibyl. She offered nine books to a king for a lot of money. He said no, so she burned three books and offered six for the same price. He said no again, so she burned three more. He finally bought the last three books for the full price. This story taught me a lesson about life. I was often lonely as a child. I wanted to play with other kids, but they said no. My mother told me to do something fun so other kids would want to join me. It worked, and I learned from it. Later, I wrote a travel book. I wanted to write about something I liked. I don't like traveling much, so I made a list of places I didn't want to go. I like to think about the past, so I wrote about old places.
**What Becomes of Your Manuscript?**
When you send your book to a publisher, it goes into a big pile. A young worker or an older person working part-time will look at it. They want to find something new and good. If they like your book, they will show it to a more important editor. The editor will decide if your book is good and if it can sell well. They will also think about if you can write more books in the future. Publishers like to meet new authors before they decide to publish their book.

**Advertising Challenges in the 1990s**
In the early 1990s, people working in advertising had a hard time. The economy was bad, and many people lost their jobs. In Britain, in 1991, the economy went down, interest rates were high, and many people stopped buying things. Over 500,000 people lost their jobs, and many homes were taken back by banks. All businesses were affected, especially car and building companies.
Advertising workers felt a lot of pressure. They had to do more work with less money. Even though times were tough, marketing became more important. Companies started to focus on making products that people wanted, not just what was easy to make. This made marketing more important, but also harder.
In the 1980s, advertising was very successful. But in the 1990s, it was difficult. The bad economy made companies look closely at how much they spent on advertising. They wanted to know if it was worth the money. Many companies were not sure if advertising was helping them.
Companies wanted better advertising strategies and creativity. They wanted the best people working hard for them. Advertising people had to find ways to do more with less money. This was hard because of the economy and other changes, like new laws and changing customer needs.
Some companies also started advertising in other countries, which was a new challenge. Everyone wanted to make sure their advertising worked well. But finding help or advice was not easy. Many companies kept their successful ideas secret. Books and seminars did not always provide good advice on how to make effective ads.

**The Lure of the Kitchen**
When I was at university, I wanted to be a chef. This was not common among my friends. Cooking is not an easy job. Chefs work long hours, the job is hard, and the pay is low. But I still wanted to be a chef. I was not happy at university. The work was difficult, and I did not enjoy the social life. Cooking seemed serious and honest, unlike my university life. I also loved the art of cooking. I first felt this when I ate at a famous restaurant in London. The meal was amazing. I wanted to learn how to cook like that. I started reading cookbooks and cooking fancy meals instead of focusing on my history degree.
**The Swimming Lesson**
The swimming teacher at school was a small, strong man with tattoos. He used to be a drill sergeant. I asked him to teach me how to dive. He told me to sit on the pool's edge, put my hands above my head, and roll forward. I practiced this for an hour. Next time, I stood up and dived off the edge. The teacher was strict. He told me to look up, keep my legs straight, and point my toes. The next week, I went to the high diving board. It was very high, and I was scared. I tried to remember what the teacher said and jumped. For a moment, I felt like I was flying. When I hit the water, my dive was not good, but I felt very happy. I understood what it means to feel 'free as a bird'.
**The Traveller**
Some people love adventure. They like to climb high mountains, sail alone in the sea, and eat strange food. They live with danger and the unknown. Many people think these travelers are strange. They live in a world different from ours. We like our comfortable beds and safe lives. We think these travelers are not important. We are happy with our microwaves and phones, and the only danger we face is crossing a busy street.
**Sailing**
Jonathan Raban is a writer who is afraid of the sea, but he spends a lot of time sailing. He is not the best sailor, but he is good. He sails because he likes to write about it. His boat has a device that tells him where he is on the sea. He likes this device, but he thinks other sea tools, like the compass, have changed how people sail. Before the compass, sailors had to watch the waves and feel the sea. Now, they just follow the compass, and the sea is just a space to cross. Raban thinks this is why he can look at the waves so closely.

**Holiday Reading**
Summer gives us two big joys: going on holiday and reading books. These joys are connected. Books help us feel at home in the world. We see our own experiences in stories from long ago or far away. In books, we find our thoughts and feelings. Authors write about things we feel but cannot say. They use clear words to show what we feel inside. This is amazing, especially if the book is from a different place or time. We thank these writers for helping us understand ourselves.
When we travel and read, we break away from our usual habits. Our eyes see new things in a new place, just like when we read a great book. Books help us notice things we missed before. We see the sky, people's faces, or feelings we didn't know we had.
**Author's Note**
These travel stories were in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I made small changes to some parts, but not much. I fixed a few mistakes. In one story about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but it didn't. I didn't change the story because it was true at that time. Travel shows us the world, even if we don't know what will happen next. We learn from what we see.
**Ecotourism**
"Ecotourism" is a popular word in travel. It started in the 1980s when people cared more about the environment. Tourists wanted to travel without harming nature. Now, "ecotourism" can mean many things, like living with tribes or a short boat trip. It includes culture, nature, and adventure. The idea was good, but without clear rules, travelers can get confused.
**Transylvanian Journey**
I lost my Transylvanian travel notes for 50 years. I found them again by luck. They helped me remember my trip. In Transylvania, I stayed in friendly homes for a long time. I stopped writing because I thought there was nothing to say. When I moved, I wrote short notes. I worried about the order of events, but then I decided to let the story tell itself.

**Fashion**
Fashion is not just a new thing. It has been around for a long time. Many people think fashion started in the 1800s and 1900s, but it is older. Fashion, like style and design, has a long history. In the 1500s and 1600s, people started trading more, and fashion began to grow. As societies grew bigger and more complex, people made more types of clothes. Clothes started to have more meanings. Today, it is hard to say what clothes mean. For example, a man's suit can mean different things to different people.
**Writer**
Many people think writers make a lot of money, but this is not true for most writers. Some writers have other jobs during the day and write at night. This way, they have money even if their book does not sell well. Other writers, like me, do many small jobs. I teach, do workshops, and write articles. I heard about a job writing for a chocolate factory, but I never got it. I write my books by doing many part-time jobs and getting help from friends.
**Sudden Fame**
Our small shows were selling out, and many fans came to see us. We had to use secret doors to get into places because of the fans. On days we did not have shows, it was hard to go outside without fans following us. In a few days, we became famous. Our fans watched us, and our managers took care of us. Even though I was shy, I started to feel more confident. But I was still not used to being famous.

**Music and the Future**
Technology is changing how we live and enjoy music. In Britain, people can listen to music on the radio, TV, CDs, and online. Because of this, there are fewer live music shows and jobs for musicians. Music is important for everyone. It is part of big events and personal activities. Music will always be here, but it might change. People might still want to learn instruments.
The music industry makes a lot of money in Britain. Playing music can help people in many jobs, especially in media. Learning music can also help children with skills like thinking and working with others. Playing an instrument can teach good habits like practicing and being on time.
In the future, music might change in two ways. First, people will listen to many different kinds of music. New styles will mix old ones. Second, technology will help people make music. This might mean fewer live shows, but more people will want to make music in their communities.
To prepare for the future, music teaching needs to change. More people should learn to play instruments at any age. Music teachers need to inspire and teach all ages. They should learn to work with big groups and have skills for community work. This is different from how music was taught before.
Music is important in our lives, but we often forget this. People in the music world need to work together to show how important music is.

**The Actor's Craft**
People sometimes make fun of actors. This happens because actors often talk about their work in interviews. They should be like the dancer Pavlova, who said, "If I could tell you, I wouldn't dance it." Instead, actors often say things that sound silly or are just gossip. Paul Scofield, a famous actor, said that acting is only interesting when you do it, not when you talk about it. Each play is new, and actors learn from the characters and the writer. When a play ends, the actor feels empty until the next one.
**A Review of Hamlet**
Adrian Lester plays Hamlet as a young man between boyhood and manhood. His acting is simple and confident. He is very good with the text and controls his body and mind well. Lester plays Hamlet as a young man who is angry but also funny and lovable. His performance is very good. When you watch him, you see how he uses his body to show his character. Acting makes us ask questions like: What is acting? What is behavior? Who controls the actors?
**One Director's Approach to Rehearsal**
This director starts rehearsals with a method called "dropping in." The stage manager shows the script on a screen. Actors listen and think about the words. When it's their turn, they read the line, think about it, and then speak. For example, if the line is "Queuing all night, the rain, do you remember?" the actor breathes, imagines the scene, and then speaks. The director says not to plan too much and to trust that something will happen.
**The Perfect Theatre**
The perfect theatre makes you feel like you matter. Going to the theatre is special, and the staff should feel that too. The theatre should connect the actors and the audience. Everyone should see and hear well. The theatre should fit the human voice and body. Old theatres often do this well because they feel like they have history. You can't please everyone with a play. People want to see something new and surprising.

**Paul Simon and Rock and Roll**
In the 1950s, rock and roll was very popular with young people. But it also changed the lives of older people and the middle class. It helped create new rock stars. Paul Simon, like many young people in the US, listened to this exciting music on the radio. Alan Freed's radio show, Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party, played this new music. Many young people, like John Lennon in England, loved listening to it. Paul Simon was very interested in the music and wanted to make his own songs.
**Snow Adventure**
I could not see a path, but I thought I would be okay if I was careful. The wind was strong and pushed me down as I walked on the ice. Suddenly, the snow under me broke, and I fell into a hole about four feet deep. The snow had covered a gap between two rocks. I climbed out, feeling scared and thinking about what could have happened if the hole was deeper. I sat by a pine tree sticking out of the snow to think about what to do next. I had walked half a mile in one hour. I knew I had to change my plan.
**Qualitative Research**
There are many books about qualitative research. These books talk a lot about collecting data but not much about how to look at the data. Many people do not know how researchers study their data. We asked different social scientists to talk about how they do it. We wanted to understand the process better, not just make a guidebook. This is not easy, so we let the scientists share their work in different ways, like telling personal stories or using more formal writing.

**Screen Learning**
A few days ago, I saw my six-year-old eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth and trying to look like a dinosaur. He said, "I'm a little dinosaur." He was copying a scene from a TV show. I asked him what he remembered about dinosaurs, but he didn't remember much. Many people like learning on the internet and computers, but is it a good way to learn? One father tried an interactive program with his son. The father read the words, but the son just played with the pictures. The father thought, "If he read a book for ten minutes, he might have learned something." TV, like my son and his noodles show, gives ideas but not much learning. Research says learning happens best with teachers or parents talking with children. New technology can help teach, but schools are still important.
**Hollywood**
By 1918, most of the world's movies were made in Hollywood. People living there didn't like it at first. They thought the movie people were rude. But they accepted it because movies made a lot of money. Hollywood knows a good movie when it sees one. A good movie can make someone a star and make a lot of money. In less than 100 years, Hollywood became as famous as New York, Rome, or Paris. It changed a lot. A long time ago, you could walk through orange trees to the store. Now, it is a busy place. People in Hollywood talk about movies, who is dating who, and who is working on what project. Successful people often want to leave Hollywood to live somewhere else. But many people in show-business still come to Hollywood.
**Photography**
Photography was invented in the 1800s by artists. They wanted to make pictures of what they saw. They used light, a lens, and chemicals to make pictures. These pictures were more real and detailed than paintings. Some artists didn't like photography at first. They said it wasn't real art because it used machines. But photographers knew they found a new way to make art. They used cameras like other artists use brushes and pencils. They showed the world and people in a new way.
**Book Illustration**
In the past, all children's books had pictures. Even books for older kids had pictures. But over time, there were fewer pictures in books. Children's books were made with little money, so some pictures were not very good. But the best artists always did their best work. The old black-and-white pictures are like a mix of junk and treasure. They are fun to look at and study. Some of these treasures are coming back. Publishers might make new books with these old pictures. They might also show them in exhibitions.

**Blogging: Sharing with the World**
A while ago, a website talked about the dangers of telling everyone where you are online. It said that when you say, "Hey, I'm here," you are also telling everyone, even people you don't know, that you are not at home. This made people think about the problems of sharing too much online. The internet lets us share everything about our lives with many people. This can be exciting because we might become famous or rich. So, we start sharing our secrets, photos, and stories online. But then we realize it can be dangerous and confusing.
Don't worry, though. Some people have already explored this online world. They were the first bloggers. They learned the hard way by losing jobs and friends and dealing with being famous. They did this before social media was popular. We can learn from their stories.
In 1994, a student named Justin Hall started sharing his life online. He wrote about everything and posted photos. People loved reading about his life. But one day, he had to stop because his girlfriend said, "It's me or the blog." He learned that sharing too much online can make people not trust you.
In 2002, Heather Armstrong wrote a blog about her life and job. But someone at her work shared her blog with her bosses, and she lost her job. This shows that what we say online can affect our real lives. Heather stopped blogging for a while but later started again, writing about her family. Now, she is a successful "mommy blogger" and earns money from her writing.
Heather learned that just because we can say anything online, it doesn't mean we should. We need to be careful about what we share.

'Enough Sleep? Many people today feel tired. In busy and rich countries, people often do not sleep enough. In the USA, 40 million people have sleep problems. Some books in Britain talk about people who cannot sleep. People are interested in sleep and why it is important. A sleep expert says, 'People need more sleep. They wake up early to avoid traffic.' 
A sleep researcher did an experiment. He let people sleep up to 14 hours a night for a month. After three weeks, they slept about eight hours a night. This shows they needed more sleep. In England, a university studies sleep. They look at how tiredness affects sailors, how noise affects sleep, and how tired drivers are dangerous. They ask students to help with their studies. Students get paid and change their sleep for the study. 
Dr. Louise Reyner works there. She says some people worry because they put things on their heads to study sleep. But they only look at physical things. In a dark room, there is a car simulator. People drive it after little or no sleep. They try not to fall asleep, but they do. A video shows a person trying to stay awake. They blink and nod off. The car goes off the road. Coffee can help. Two cups can make you a safe driver for a short time. Dr. Reyner suggests coffee, energy drinks, and gum to stay awake. 
We know some things about sleep. People sleep in cycles. There are four stages of sleep. Dreams happen in light sleep. The brain stops the body from moving during dreams. Scientists think sleep helps the body and brain, but they are not sure. Women sleep more than men, and older people need less sleep. 
In the past, people slept differently. From 1500 to 1850 in Britain, people had 'first sleep' and 'morning sleep.' They woke up in the night for an hour. They used this time to think or do things. As lights became common, people started sleeping like we do now. The industrial revolution made people work longer, so they slept less. In some places, people still sleep in short times, not all night. They wake up to watch for danger. Many people need more sleep.'

I was wearing very expensive cowboy boots in the Arizona desert. I had a full cowboy outfit, but I was not a real cowboy. I came from Denver and thought I might look like a cowboy. But when I saw a real cowboy at the airport, I knew I was not one. He wore an old T-shirt and carried a dirty bag. He looked at my new boots and left without saying anything.
I used to be a racing driver, and I loved it. But I don't race anymore. I don't know what to do now. I tried to be a commentator for races, but many other drivers wanted that job too. I also tried to sell old cars, but nobody was buying them.
Being an "ex" racing driver is hard. People don't want to hear about how I almost became a champion. Even if I was a champion, people would only listen for a short time. I miss driving fast cars and being famous. Now, I have a lot of free time. 
In the desert, I saw some birds singing. I realized I have a lot to learn.

**Vancouver**
In the last ten years, many people from all over the world have moved to Vancouver, in western Canada. In the evening, people like to walk in the city. If you walk with them, you will hear many different languages. People come to Vancouver because it has nice weather, beautiful places with the ocean and mountains, and it is clean and safe. There are also good schools and jobs. Some people complain about new buildings, but new people and tourists have helped the city grow. Vancouver was once called 'Terminal City' because it was a starting point to other places. Now, it is even more of a gateway.
**Writing Letters**
Journalists like me are not good at writing letters. Some say it is because we do not get paid for letters, but I do not think that is true. In our work, we try to make a big impact, so writing a simple letter is hard for us. Real artists do not have this problem. They know how to use words well. When Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he did not think about using big words, but he was still a great writer.
**Supermarket Opening**
In the past, opening a new supermarket in Britain was a big event. A famous person would come to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets open all the time, so they do not need famous people. Last week, at a new Superbuy store, people did not care who opened it. They just wanted to be first in line. The first five men got a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women got flowers. People at the front of the line were happy, and people who came late were jealous.

**Citizen Kane**
The movie "Citizen Kane" came out in 1941. At first, it was not very popular. People were worried because the movie was about a man like William Randolph Hearst, a powerful newspaper owner. But later, TV made the movie famous. Many people who make movies today say "Citizen Kane" inspired them. This is amazing because it was Orson Welles's first movie. Welles said he didn't know what he could or couldn't do, so he just did what he wanted. He had a great team, like cameraman Gregg Toland and writer Herman J. Mankiewicz. Welles and Mankiewicz decided to make a movie about a newspaper boss like Hearst. Welles was excited to direct and act in the movie.
**Dermot and Carmel**
Dermot thought Carmel was acting strange that morning. He told her he might be late and might stop at the golf club. He needed to talk to someone there. Carmel just nodded like she didn't really hear him. Dermot asked her what she would do that day. Carmel said she had nothing to do, so she would walk around town and look at shops. She thought it was nice to relax. Dermot said she should enjoy herself and not worry about making dinner if he was late. Carmel agreed.
**Job Titles**
A study showed that job titles can make people feel jealous at work. Many bosses and workers say titles can cause problems. The study found that many workers would rather have a better job title than a pay raise. People want titles that sound important, like "specialist" or "coordinator." This shows that people don't like being called less important.

I was in Vienna to take photos. Taking photos was my job and my passion. I loved how light looked on things and how one photo could show the feeling of a place or person. I always hoped to take the perfect photo. I had a lucky moment once when a photo I took of smoke from an oil well was wanted by newspapers everywhere. After that, I worked for myself, but things didn't go as planned. That's why I was in Vienna, not somewhere more exciting. But I was still happy to take photos and get paid for it.
I got the Vienna job by chance. I had taken photos in London for a book about four cities in four seasons: London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. The Austrian photographer quit, so they asked me to take his place. I was free, and they liked my work. Things at home weren't good, so I was happy to go to Vienna.
They put me in a hotel in the old city. I had been to Vienna before with my wife, but it was busy and hot, and I didn't take many photos. This time, in cold January, it felt different. I knew I would enjoy it and take great photos.
The first day, I just rode the trams around the city to see everything. I wanted to make Vienna my own. A photo is a moment, and I waited for the right moment. The next morning, I went out early. The snow made the city look beautiful. I wanted to take a photo of the big cathedral, but it was hard to fit it all in one picture. Still, I knew it could be magical. Photography has always felt magical to me, like when you watch a photo appear on paper. Even when you know how it works, it still feels like a mystery. That's why what happened that morning didn't surprise me.

**Kinetic Art Exhibition**
Something amazing has happened at London's Hayward Gallery. It is now a place full of wonder. This change is not because of a big, expensive show. Instead, it is because of a special exhibition about kinetic art. Kinetic art is art that moves or shows movement. This exhibition looks at the history of kinetic art in the 20th century. It shows that art with movement has been important for many years. The exhibition has paintings, drawings, documents, and films. Guy Brett, who knows a lot about kinetic art, put it all together. There are not many explanations, so visitors can enjoy and discover things on their own.
**David Hockney**
David Hockney is an artist many people like. His art is easy to understand because it shows real things. People might like his art because it is about fun and escape from everyday life. Some people might like Hockney because he is funny and interesting. Some critics think Hockney is not a great artist. But maybe he is popular because people like him, not because his art is bad. Hockney knows he is not the best artist. He thinks only time will tell how good his art really is.
**Window-shopping - An Art Exhibition**
I have seen many art shows. Some are great, and some are not. Some shows try to say all the artists think the same way. I wanted to do something different. I worked with seven artists in an empty warehouse. We called it "Window-shopping." Each artist made their own art. Sam Cole made knitted cats that moved on a toy train track. Matthew Crawley used a video camera until it broke. These artworks are very different, but they work well together. I did not try to make a big statement about art. Art is personal, and each artist decides what they want to do.
**Art History**
Some people love looking at paintings but do not want to study them. They think studying might ruin the fun. Some art historians focus on theory and not on enjoying art. But knowing more about art can make it more enjoyable. Our likes are not just about us; they are also about what society values. Enjoying art is important, but thinking about it can also be interesting. In the past, people thought art was different from thinking. But now, we know that enjoying and thinking about art can go together.

**Metals**
A long time ago, people in the Stone Age found metals. They might have found a shiny yellow stone, like gold, by a river. It was not like other stones. It was soft and pretty. People liked it very much. They also found copper. Copper is good for making tools. People learned how to get copper from rocks. This was an important skill for them.
**St Ives**
We walked down a small street in St Ives. It was very windy and cold. The sea waves were big and hit the road. No one was outside. The houses were closed up tight. We came to St Ives by train. The weather was bad. I wanted to show my friend the nice coast and warm fires, but the weather was not good.
**Computer Modelling**
Studying the past is hard because it is gone. We cannot see how people lived long ago. We can find old things, but we cannot test ideas about them. But now, we can use computers to help. Computers can make old places and people. We can see how they might have lived. We can change things, like rain or people, and see what happens.

**Vervet Monkeys**
Cheney and Seyfarth studied vervet monkeys. One day, the leader male monkey saw a new male monkey near their trees. The new monkey wanted to join the group. If he joined, the leader might lose his place. The leader monkey had a smart idea to keep the new monkey away. When the new monkey tried to come closer, the leader made a loud call. This call means a leopard is near. The new monkey got scared and ran back to his trees. This happened many times. But then, the leader made a mistake. He made the leopard call while he was walking calmly. 
**What Cats Catch**
In a village in England, people counted what their cats caught. In one year, 70 cats caught over 1,000 animals. A professor in America thought all cats in Britain might catch 100 million birds and small animals each year. But this is not true. Most cats live in towns and catch fewer animals. The important question is: are there still enough birds? The answer is yes. People feed birds in winter, and birds have places to live in gardens. Cats do catch many birds, but they are not destroying the bird population.
**Buffalo's Day**
Buffaloes are very important to marsh people. Every morning, buffaloes leave their sleeping place slowly. They make tired sounds as they go to the water. They stand at the edge, making noises about the hard day ahead. Finally, the leader buffalo goes into the water. They move slowly and look tired, but they swim to the reeds. They spend the day eating green plants in the water.
**PICASSO, Pablo**
In 1940, Picasso painted fish while he was in a fishing town. The painting shows a fish seller's table with a crab and some fish. The fish look alive. The painting is flat with soft colors, like an underwater world. But there is tension. The fish and crab look like they might fight. The sharp shapes in the painting add to this feeling. There is a sense of danger in the picture.

Photography
For about 150 years, photography has helped us see and remember many parts of life. It lets us see things that happen quickly and things that are very big or very small. We can see pictures from faraway places on Earth and even from space. Photography shows us the world and helps us understand life.
Long ago, people made pictures on cave walls. These pictures are very old, about 35,000 years old. We don't know why they made them. Maybe they showed hunting, helped with magic, or were just for fun. But pictures have always been important to people.
When photography was invented in the 1800s, people thought it showed the truth. The camera works like our eyes and can make a picture that looks real. This was a big change for art and culture. People thought everyone could understand photos, no matter where they were from. But we still wonder if photos mean the same thing to everyone.
Photos are very common now. We use them to show things, like when we say, "This is my grandson," and show a picture. Since 1839, photography has changed a lot. Photos used to help us remember things, but now they are also part of history. They tell us about the people and times when they were taken.
Photography is not just about taking pictures. It can help change the world. Like in the past, new ways of seeing things helped change art and culture. Today, photography is a big part of our media and helps us see the world in new ways.

**How to Write Poetry**
Writing poetry can be tricky. There are no strict rules, but reading a lot and writing often can help. Some people need to feel happy to write, while others write when they are sad. Some write every day, and others wait for a special idea. All ways are okay if you listen to your own voice inside. This voice will grow stronger with time.
**The Short Story**
In a short story, you can't have too many characters or long descriptions. Flashbacks should be short and only used if needed. A memory can help move the story forward. Dialogue, or talking between characters, can show different sides of a story quickly. Every word in a short story is important, so make them count.
**Screenplays**
Writing a screenplay is like playing chess. At first, you might not know what will happen next. But as you play more, you start to see the whole game. You learn about strategy and patterns. The more you write, the better you understand how it works.
**Looking at Writing**
Speaking is natural for humans, but writing is not. All children learn to speak without lessons. Writing systems were created by a few old civilizations and have changed over time. Not all children learn to read and write easily. Writing is like a tool that we need to learn how to use.

I have never started a book with more worry. I call it a book because I don't know what else to call it. I have a small story to tell, and it doesn't end with a death or a marriage. I leave my reader wondering. This book is about my memories of a man I met only sometimes, and I don't know much about what happened to him in between. I could make up things to fill the gaps and make the story clearer, but I don't want to do that. I just want to write what I know. To protect people who are still alive, I have changed their names and made sure no one can recognize them. The man I write about is not famous. Maybe he never will be. When he dies, he might not leave any mark on the world, like a stone thrown into a river leaves no mark on the water. If my book is read, it will be for its own interest. But maybe his way of life and his strong and kind character will influence others, and people will realize he was special. Then, people who want to know about his early life might find something useful in my book. I think my book will help people who want to write about my friend. I don't say that the conversations I wrote are exactly what was said. I didn't take notes, but I remember well, and I believe I have written them truthfully. I have made up some parts to make the story more lively, like historians do. I want people to read my book, so I have tried to make it interesting. Readers can decide for themselves what to believe. Another reason I am worried about this book is that the people I write about are from another culture. It is hard to know people from other countries. People are shaped by where they are born, the games they played, the food they ate, and the schools they went to. You can only really know them if you have lived like them. Because of this, it is hard to make them seem real in a book. I usually write about people from my own country. In short stories, you can give a quick idea of a character and let the reader imagine the rest. In this book, I don't pretend my characters see themselves as I see them. They are seen through my eyes.

**Poetry Readings**
Today, there are many different types of poetry and ways to share it. Some poets write poems to be read in books, while others like to perform their poems in front of people. This has created two groups: poets who focus on writing and poets who focus on performing.
In the last 20 years, more people have started to enjoy poetry readings. These events happen in small towns, schools, and festivals. Some poets write simple poems that are easy to understand when heard. These poets do well in performances because their poems are made for listening.
Other poets write complex poems that are best read on paper. These poets might not be understood well in a live reading because their work is more detailed and deep. They might choose to read their simpler poems to connect with the audience quickly.
Listening to poetry is fun and can help people enjoy it more. It is good to hear poets read their own work, even if they are not great speakers. It helps listeners understand the poems better. Sometimes, poetry readings include music to make them more enjoyable.
The main goal of poetry readings is to show people that poetry can be fun and for everyone, not just for a few people who study it a lot.

**Oral History**
Historians are using more oral stories, but this has problems. When someone tells their story, it is not always a clear picture of the past. The historian and the person telling the story can affect each other. The historian chooses who to talk to and what to talk about. Even if the historian just listens, their presence can change how the person remembers and talks about the past. The final story is influenced by the historian's position and how they understand history. Historians help create new evidence, but the person telling the story is also not directly connected to the past. Their memories can be mixed with things they heard from other places, like TV. They might remember the past as better than it was or feel upset about things that happened later. Feelings can make the story seem true, but they might come from later events, not the past.
**Animal Science**
There are two main ways to study animals: looking at how their bodies work and looking at their behavior. Physiologists study how nerves, muscles, and senses work together. People who study the whole animal look at how animals behave and what affects them. In this group, psychologists study how animals learn, often in labs with rats and pigeons. Ethologists study natural behavior in wild animals. These two groups are now working more together. Physiologists think their methods are very important, but even if we know how every nerve works, we still need to study behavior. Behavior has its own patterns that we need to understand. Describing a bird building a nest by looking at nerve cells is like trying to read a book with a microscope.
**The Social Sciences**
When students start learning social sciences, they need to do two things at once. They need to learn the content of the subject and the methods used to study it. This means understanding the information in textbooks and how this information is found and organized. Social sciences are not just common sense. Each social science looks at a different part of social life, uses different study methods, and has its own ideas. These ideas help social scientists go beyond everyday understanding and make each subject unique.
**Classical Architecture**
In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building. The Roman architect Vitruvius said architecture is about order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, and distribution. He used some Greek words for these ideas, which came from earlier Greek writings. Vitruvius did not focus on how useful buildings were, but on their beauty. Classical architecture started with simple huts in Greece and Italy. These huts were not artistic but gave important ideas for later buildings. Even if a classical temple looks fancy, it is basically a simple, single-room hut.

The two sisters, Lily and Mui, kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily drove around the area, sometimes making mistakes like bumping the car. Chen found out but was amused. He said, "So you can really drive, Lily? Well done!" Mui thought Chen should be upset, but he was happy and planned a trip with Lily. They decided to go on a Monday morning and come back by midday to not lose customers. Lily practiced driving, and Mui bought a map with a discount, which impressed Chen. 
On the trip, Lily drove very well. Even Mui, who was ready to give directions, agreed. Lily overtook some slow cars, and Chen clapped. They reached the seaside and parked. Lily was careful about parking rules and paid a fee to avoid problems. She locked the van doors carefully. Chen joked that no one would want their old van, which upset the sisters. Chen then took their son, Man Kee, to see the sea. He thought about Man Kee's future, wanting him to have a good education and own many restaurants.
Chen saw a ship through a telescope and told Man Kee it was special, like them. He said it would take them home one day. Lily and Mui joined them, and Lily tried to see the ship, but it was gone. She only saw seagulls in the telescope.

Title: The Well
I read that if you look from a deep hole, you can see stars during the day. I asked you to help me try this. You watched as I pulled up the well bucket and climbed in. I told you to lower me down. I didn't think about how heavy the bucket would be or that you might not be strong enough. You held the handle, but when I moved the bucket, I fell into the well. I hit my head and saw strange lights. Later, I realized they looked like stars in cartoons when someone gets hit.
At first, I was confused, then scared, then angry at you for letting me fall. You called down to ask if I was okay. I was about to shout back, but you called again, sounding scared, and I stayed quiet. You ran to get help. I climbed out of the well and hid. I heard voices from the castle. I saw water drops on the ground from my wet clothes. I was scared they would find me.
Mother and Father came with you and Arthur. Mother was screaming, and Father told Arthur to use the winch. I hid in the shadows, feeling excited but also worried. I saw the water drops shining in the sun and couldn't believe no one noticed them. I knew I had to do something. I came out of hiding, pretending to be hurt. I told them I found a secret tunnel from the well to the moat and crawled out.
Father asked me to repeat my story. I added that the tunnel collapsed, so no one could check it. Father didn't believe me. He looked at me like he was seeing me for the first time. He told me not to be ridiculous and walked away. Arthur looked at me sadly, knowing I was lying. His look made me feel bad, like my father's words. I realized they both saw through my lie, and it made me think about how lying was wrong.

**Moving Day**
Susan is a widow. Her children are grown up. She has to leave her family home. A van is outside. It says "Removers of Distinction." Fred is the removal man. He is packing everything in boxes. His fingers are big but gentle. His helpers are not so gentle.
Susan's house is lovely. It has four floors and looks at a small harbour. She remembers her children growing up there. Robert, her son, is helping. He is now an adult. He remembers asking, "Mum, when you buy a house, how do you get it home?" Francesca, her daughter, is also helping. She is careful with the piano.
Fred says, "She doesn't look like she's going to cry." Susan asks, "Do people cry?" Fred says, "Yes, they cry when everything is in the van. But they are fine at the new place."
Susan remembers when they moved in. The piano got stuck on the stairs. Her husband, Peter, fixed the problem. They used a crane to bring the piano through a window. It was expensive, so they couldn't tune the piano for months.
Now, Susan is moving out. She is sad but also happy. The piano is the last thing to move. Fred and his team carry it out. Susan, Robert, and Francesca laugh with relief. They walk down the path together, arm in arm, laughing. The only tears Susan has are tears of laughter.

**Online Book Reviews for Everyone**
Writing about books online: is it just for fun? When the Internet started, anyone could share their ideas. You could write about anything or start a music channel. But you needed some computer skills back then. 
One area that became open to everyone was book reviews. On Amazon.com, a big online bookshop, anyone could write what they thought about a book and give it up to five stars. This was a great idea because people could see what other readers thought, not just what the publisher or professional critics said.
Amazon was the biggest online bookshop, so it had the most reviews. But this also meant some people tried to cheat. Many reviews were posted every day, so Amazon couldn't check them all. They had rules: no bad words, no spoilers, and no personal attacks. But people could still be sneaky. 
For example, some writers wrote fake good reviews for their own books. One writer, Lev Grossman, did this because he got bad reviews. He wrote nice things about his book until he got caught. 
Authors could also comment on their books. Most just said they hoped people would like their book. Some even shared their email to talk to readers. But Amazon didn't always check if the comments were really from the author, except for famous writers.
Sometimes, readers got very upset. When James McElroy's book about cheerleaders came out, some people in the book were angry and wrote bad reviews on Amazon. These reviews disappeared after a few days.
Amazon liked that people spent time writing reviews because it helped their business. They watched popular books closely to make sure reviews followed the rules. Funny reviews were usually on less popular books. For example, a children's book called "The Story about Ping" got funny reviews because "ping" is also a computer term.
Most reviews on Amazon were serious and helped people decide if a book was good. The writer George Orwell once said that writing too many reviews was hard because you had to pretend to have feelings about books you didn't care about. So, letting everyone write reviews was a good idea.

**Art in Modern Times**
In the last 200 years, people think artists must be different from others. We like art that is new and surprising. We admire artists whose work was not liked 100 years ago. But today, we sometimes say an artist's work is not art. The media often say this, and we agree. We want artists to be special and different. In the past, people asked artists to make art for them. Now, artists work alone, and we get upset if they try to be like everyone else.
**Picture This**
Let me tell you a story and ask a question. An artist picks some words from a book about art. The words say there are many kinds of pictures. The artist asks someone to make a canvas and take it to a sign painter. The sign painter writes the words on the canvas in simple black letters. My question is: Is this a painting?
**Underground Encounters**
At the Mercury Gallery in London until June 26th
Artists often stick to one style to be successful. People like to see the same kind of art from an artist. But some artists try new things. Picasso and Hockney did this. Eric Rimmington is another artist trying something new. He used to paint still lifes. Now, he paints the London Underground. He likes trains and started drawing them in the 1980s. His new show has 40 paintings and drawings of the Underground.
**Extract from a Novel**
I went to an island with some books. People say only a sick person would go to such a quiet place. I am here to feel better. A woman from the village comes to clean the house. I am alone. I am not happy or sad. I think about the past. Art is not always useful, but it can make us feel better. Artists can change reality with their work. Art helps us understand life better. It is not to escape life, but to see its true meaning. Why should we hurt each other?

Title: Family Talk
My dad said, "This is not good!" We were driving back to London. My dad and my brother Maurice had just picked me up from my school. I had won two prizes at school: one for Latin and one for doing well in exams. My dad talked with my headteacher, and now we were going home for the holidays.
"What is not good?" I asked, but I knew what he was thinking. My dad usually talked a lot, but he was quiet now. "You will do what you want," he said. "You have many certificates. They say you can get a scholarship to Oxford."
"So?" I said. "Isn't that good?"
"I hear you want to be a barrister," he said. A barrister is a lawyer. My dad knew a lot about lawyers. "I just said that," I replied. "I didn't know what else to say!"
"They say you are good at talking and understanding things quickly," he continued. "You like performing."
"I don't know," I said. "I just watch TV shows about it."
"Anyway," he said, "I think you won't want to work in our family business. You will go to Oxford, and then you won't want to join us."
I felt trapped by family expectations. I wanted to try different jobs, but I didn't want to upset my dad. I was his favorite, but he was still a strong person.
"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.
"You won't want to join us," my dad said. "You have the brains and the vision."
"There's still Maurice," I said. We both knew Maurice didn't like the business.
"You can help us during holidays until you finish at Oxford," my dad said. "It will give you some money and help me."
"OK," I said, happy to not make a decision now. My dad would get upset if I said no.
So, I helped during holidays, never more than twice a year. I became a smart student with nice things. In my last term, my dad visited me. He said he needed me for one last job. It was important for our family business.
"But Dad," I said, "I have my final exams soon. I need to focus on them."
My dad didn't understand. He thought I was leaving him when he needed me. I saw how focused and smart he was. He was like a genius. I respected him.
"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake after living there for a year with his wife, Lois. They could only afford it by being very careful with money. At first, it seemed like a good idea because Simon had many successful cases, and Lois got a raise at her advertising job, making thirty-five thousand. Lois wanted to move because their flat was too small for a family, and they needed more space and a garden. They could have found a bigger place in a cheaper area, but Lois wanted a better address for their social status.
Lois decided that one of them should use public transport to save money. Since her job was far away, Simon had to take the crowded tube, which made him unhappy. He thought about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he was treated well after a long day. But times had changed, and Lois made it clear that her career was as important as his. They needed both their salaries to maintain their lifestyle.
Now, their life could be ruined by Venetia, who was very angry with Simon. She accused him of knowing that a client, Brian Cartwright, bribed the jury four years ago and did nothing about it. She also said Cartwright gave shares to Simon's fiancÃ©e before the trial. Simon denied it, but he felt guilty and scared. He wished he had been prepared for her accusations. He knew he should have said Cartwright was lying, but he panicked and lied instead. Venetia didn't believe him, and he worried she could ruin his career.

I chose to live here because I thought people wouldn't notice me. I hoped they wouldn't care about broken houses or messy gardens. But I was wrong. People in the shops started to recognize me. The roses next door remind me that the gardens were once loved. I usually stay inside, but tonight I am watching birds fly. I cleared some plants to make space for a chair, and my arms are scratched. It's a small London garden where plants grow tall. 
My neighbor, Jaz, leans out of the window. She writes books that aren't published, and I sometimes talk about them because I teach English. I have her latest book now. 'How's the work going, Jaz?' I ask. 'In no other job do people ask about your work so much,' she says. 'I'll bring a drink down,' she adds. I don't want Jaz in the garden, and it looks messy. The only way to the garden is through my flat, and Jaz knocks on my door. 'You're on holiday now,' she says, sitting in a chair. 'Cheers,' she says. 'I should've been a teacher - writers don't get holidays. They say, those who can, do, those who can't, teach.' 
'So, what plans for the holidays?' she asks. I feel worried about the empty days. I think about walking to the shops and sitting alone in the park. 'I'm going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed the cats?' I ask. 'Of course,' Jaz says. 'If I'm around,' she adds, knowing she will be. 'Where will you stay?' she asks. 'With my friend Ruby at the Rising Sun,' I say. It's not true, but I often deal with stories. 'Going back to your roots. What do you think of my book?' Jaz asks. I haven't read much of her book, The Cruelty of Red Vans. I like the title and tell her. 
'Let me give you a tip,' I say. 'What?' she asks. 'Try writing about nice people, people who want to be good,' I suggest. 'Teachers!' Jaz says, upset. 'I keep a journal and write something good about each day,' I say. 'Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann,' Jaz replies. I have a life. I work, go out, and read on the train. When we go inside, I remember my old teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who would wink and say, 'I've had my moments.' We laughed a lot.

**Heritage**
Heritage is about feeling connected to the past. We often know about our grandparents and their stories. Learning about our past helps us understand our future. Heritage is like a bridge from the past to the future. It is part of our history and culture, passed down from many generations. Even if there are parts of our heritage we don't like, it is still ours. Heritage teaches us a lot and is important for our well-being. It includes customs and things we use. In the past, we learned about heritage through stories from our ancestors. Now, we also learn from old buildings and places. It is important to keep these places safe to remember our ancestors.
**The Fens**
I wrote a book called "Waterland" about a place in England called the Fens. I chose the Fens because they seemed simple and empty, but I found out they are not. The Fens are a special part of England, both wild and full of life. They are mysterious and different from other places. I did not visit many places in the Fens, but I imagined them in my book. The Fens are not just a place; they are also a feeling.
**Museums**
Museums show us real things from the past. Before, museums just put things in cases with long labels. Now, they try to make displays fun and interesting. Museums should be for everyone. They can lend objects to schools and help people with memory problems. Museums have real items that were used in history. This makes them different from theme parks or books. Museums that make their displays exciting will help people want to see the real things.
**Architecture and Environment**
People have always wanted to keep things from the past. Today, towns change quickly, and this affects us. Some people want to keep everything the same, while others think about how towns should be in the future. People who lived through big events, like wars, may want to keep things stable. If people need to keep things the same, planners should think about it. Change is not bad if we know how to manage it. Changes in towns show changes in our lives and needs.

**Einstein**  
If you ask someone to name a scientist, they will probably say Albert Einstein. His face is used in ads for smart things like computers and books. Many people don't know much about what Einstein did, but they know he made theories called 'relativity'. These theories are famous for being hard to understand. Einstein helped change how we think about science. He looked at time, space, matter, and energy in a new way. Before Einstein, people believed in Isaac Newton's idea that space and time were the same everywhere. Einstein said that time and space are not the same for everyone.
**Young Readers**  
When we were kids, Lydia and I did not like books that won prizes because we thought they were boring. Our mom did not like this, but our dad would give us money to read these books. He also gave us some good books as gifts, saying they were not just for fun. We thought most of these books were for boys, but we did read some short stories and poems.
**Language**  
In 1851, Jacob Grimm said that the start of human language is a big mystery. Many people have strange ideas about how language began. In 1928, Charles Caller said early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they were scared. Some people thought these sounds became words like "malaria" for "fever" or "mors" for "death". Because of these odd ideas, many people did not talk about how language started. But now, it is an important topic for research. Language probably started in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. People used it to talk to each other and for power. Sharing information was not the main reason for language at first.

'Writing Reviews Frank Kermode talks about how to write reviews. Reviews are short and often forgotten quickly. They have deadlines and must be short. When published, they last only as long as the newspaper or magazine they are in. People often think writing reviews is not important work. Some writers do it for extra money or because they can't work on big projects all the time. But writing reviews is a skill. It is different to write a short review for a newspaper and a long one for a journal. Reviewers must think about who will read their review. They need to know a lot about many things and write clearly. Many reviewers also write other things, like books. For example, the American writer John Updike writes reviews when he is not writing novels. He collects his reviews in books. Some people think reviews should not last, but others like to keep them. Kermode, who is a professor, writes reviews and books. In English-speaking countries, it is normal for professors to write reviews. This is good for readers because they know the reviewer understands the topic. It is also good for professors because it helps them communicate clearly. Writing reviews is a secondary job. You can do it well if you also do other work well.'

Ralph opened the door to his apartment. It was dark and quiet inside. Even after three years, he sometimes felt unsure about owning it. When he first bought the apartment, he was excited to come home. He wondered what the apartment was like when he was not there. It felt like a safe place for him. He thought he should worry about things like burglars or broken pipes, but the apartment was always waiting for him. Sometimes it was tidy, and sometimes it was messy.
Ralph started to see the apartment as part of himself. It was a place where he could relax. Sometimes there were letters by the door or messages on the answering machine. He was glad nothing bad happened to his apartment while he was away. From his boring office, Ralph looked forward to being home alone a few nights a week. After work, he felt like himself again on the bus ride home. At work, he wanted to be alone, but when he got home, he felt empty.
