Ralph often read books or listened to music at night. He wondered why he did these things. He felt lost and confused. He remembered a time when he felt stronger and thought he could have done something different with his life. After university, he wanted to make a plan for his future, but he just wanted to get by. He applied for jobs his friends talked about and followed their paths. He went to one job interview for a local newspaper. He was happy to have a nice talk with Neil, his boss. Neil gave him the job because he was the only graduate who applied. Ralph thought this was a compliment.

**Goat Racing**
I was going to see goat racing. It was Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. There were many people, ice-cream vans, food stalls, and loud music. Everyone was moving to the racecourse. I pushed through the crowd to find a good spot. A place was marked for the race. It was not like big racecourses, but people stood on both sides to watch. Some people tried to keep the goats in order. It was hard because goats like to eat everything.
**Canoe Trip**
As the day ended, I was scared about the night. The canoe was too wet to sleep in. We did not see any villages or huts since morning. In the moonlight, we used a torch to see the cliffs. The torch batteries were low, so we put in new ones, but they did not work. We could not find a place to camp. A few miles later, Lesley saw a light, and we were happy. But it was just moonlight on the water. We heard loud water, but we could not see it. Time felt slow, and we kept moving.
**How to be Good at Presentations**
I am not good at making presentations. But as a managing director, I need to present to my colleagues and shareholders. How can I get better and feel more confident? You are not alone. Presenting is different from running a company. Many senior executives need to be good at it. To convince others, you must believe in what you say. Show your belief with passion and enthusiasm. Do your homework. Test your ideas before. Ask colleagues about hard questions the audience might ask. Start with something everyone agrees on and slowly reach your conclusion.

Some things take time and cannot be rushed. If you hurry, you might make mistakes. For example, if you add oil too fast when making mayonnaise, it will not turn out right. If you pull too hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot gets worse. Our minds also work at different speeds. Some things we can do quickly, like solving puzzles. But other things need more time, like thinking deeply or solving big problems.
There are three speeds of thinking. The first is very fast, like when you react quickly to something. For example, if you are about to fall, your body moves fast to keep you safe. This is called using your 'wits'. 
The second speed is slower and involves thinking things through. This is when you solve problems or make decisions. We call this 'intellect'. People who are good at this are often called 'clever'.
The third speed is the slowest. It is when you think in a relaxed way, like when you are daydreaming or just sitting quietly. This is important for creativity and wisdom. Sometimes, thinking slowly helps us understand complex problems better.
Scientists are learning more about this slow thinking. It can help us see patterns and solve difficult problems. It is important to give our minds time to think slowly, just like we need time to rest.

**Amateur Astronomy**
Astronomy has changed a lot in the last 50 years. 30 years ago, there were not many charts or books about astronomy. Telescopes were not very good. Now, you can buy many different telescopes and equipment. Computers help make charts and analyze observations. This is a great time for amateur astronomy. But, some things are not as good. You might need to travel far to see a clear sky. Airplanes make trails in the sky that can turn into clouds. This makes it hard to watch the sky during the day and night.
**Too Much Choice**
Today, there are too many choices. There are many things to do and buy. New products come out very fast. This can make people feel tired and stressed. More choices mean more stress and less time. People now look for simple things that make life better. But, it is hard to make life simple because there are too many products. There are many types of soap and cereal, and many phone plans. It is hard to keep track of everything.
**McAndrews Hotel**
Every summer, we stay for two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. It is a family tradition started by my grandmother. We do not let anything change this tradition. The people who stay at McAndrews are old-fashioned and polite. I do not like rude shop assistants or waiters who act too friendly. I know many guests at the hotel because they have been coming here since they were children. We greet each other politely but do not talk much. It is nice to have privacy and respect, which is hard to find in hotels today.

**Othello**
A special show of Shakespeare's play "Othello" moved from Stratford to London. I want to say sorry for a bad review I wrote when the show started last spring. I said Ray Fearon was too young to play Othello and I was wrong about his acting. I still think Othello should be older than Desdemona, but Ray Fearon's acting is great. The whole cast is great. There are memorable scenes, like when Cassio plays games with other officers and things get out of control, and when Iago starts to lose control. The scene where Emilia helps Desdemona get ready for bed is very moving. The show is exciting and full of tension. Don't miss it.
**Lake Vostok**
In the middle of Antarctica, it is very quiet. There are many penguins, seals, and birds at the edges of the continent. But in the center, there is no life. Except for a big hidden lake called Lake Vostok, under almost 4 kilometers of ice. It is the coldest place on earth. The water has been without air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Scientists are excited to explore the lake and find out what strange creatures live there. Geologists and glaciologists are also interested. For two years, scientists from around the world have been planning to discover the lake's secrets. In the next few years, we will learn more about Lake Vostok.
**Scientists**
There was something interesting on the radio last week. Some scientists are talking about why they want to be scientists. They want to know why we want to learn about everything, like atoms and black holes. They wonder why science can't explain why we want to know things. It is important to know if what scientists do is right, instead of just talking about why we do it. Science is a tool, and we should decide how to use it.

**Food**
Food is important and makes us happy. Many people like cooking. You don't need a special day or a fancy dish to cook. You can make a tasty soup with carrots, a leek, celery, and herbs in water. This is better than buying soup in a packet or can. Instead of buying chocolate mousse with many chemicals, you can make a delicious one in five minutes. Cooking shows care and love. We often eat together at parties like birthdays and weddings. We don't eat takeaway food for these special days.
**In the Elevator**
Alistair tried to clean his office, but papers were everywhere. He had many tax forms and papers for his apartment building. Books and journals were not on the shelves. He knew Mallory would be on time for their meeting. She liked things to be neat and on time. Alistair wondered what she would think of the mess. Mrs. Wilson, the cleaning lady, came while he was cleaning. She did not want to clean his office. She only cleaned his apartment.
**Karen**
Karen wanted to be different from her mother. When she was twelve, her brother hit her eye with a golf club. She thought she was blind, but the doctor said she was okay. She had a few stitches. Her mother talked about miracles. Karen felt she was saved for a reason.
**Miss Fogerty**
Miss Fogerty walked across the grass, feeling both happy and sad. She learned something new in her small village. She was sad because Dr. Bailey, her doctor, was not well. He helped her with her throat problems every year. Dr. Bailey was kind and listened to his patients. The village loved him for this.

**Joanna's Lessons**
Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. She also writes books for young children learning the piano. Joanna is very good at playing the piano. She plays many types of music like classical, jazz, and blues. At a concert for kids, a boy asked her to play "Match of the Day." Joanna found it funny and played it for him. 
Joanna cares about how children learn the piano. She wrote a book called "Joanna MacGregor's Piano World" for beginners. Even though she is very busy, she made time to write this book. She believes the first lessons are very important. Joanna wants music to be for everyone, not just for very talented children.
When Joanna was young, many children came to her house to learn piano from her mother. She saw children from different backgrounds wanting to play all kinds of music. Joanna thinks everyone should try to learn the piano, just like learning to swim or speak a little French.
Some children learn piano quickly, but others take more time. Joanna is interested in helping all children enjoy music. She worries that some parents push their children too hard to be like kids on TV. She wants children to enjoy music, not feel pressure.
Joanna's books are colorful and fun. They have stories and CDs with music to help children learn. She thinks learning should be fun. Children should try different things on the piano, like playing high and low notes.
As children learn more, they need to practice reading music. Joanna knows practice is important. She practices a lot now, but she didn't always. She says practice is the most important part of her music life. She suggests setting goals for practice and mixing easy and hard pieces.

**Writing by Hand and on Screen**
Dr. Johnson said that writing without effort is not enjoyable to read. Good writing is hard work. When I look at my old school essays, I see few mistakes. Today, I would rewrite them many times. Writing by hand was hard, so I wrote carefully. Computers make writing easy, but also sloppy. Many writers spend a lot of time fixing their computer drafts. Emails are not as personal as handwritten letters. But emails have brought back love letters. Many people now write love emails. But words on a screen can feel boring. People who write on computers often exaggerate. Printed words written quickly lack the care of handwriting.
**The CD**
I looked at the CD. The case was not special, but the disc was shiny. Mr. Warriston said CDs are amazing because they hold a lot of music. He showed me how to play it. He said some people think CDs sound too clean, but he likes them. I asked if you need to turn them over like records. He said no, you only play one side. He didn't know why both sides aren't used. He thought it was a good question. He wanted me to sit in the best place to hear the music. I was happy to ask a question he couldn't answer.
**Books versus Electronic Text**
Malcolm Bradbury said if matches came after lighters, we would think they are better. People say electronic text is a big change like printing. But changes take time. In 1979, a book said books would disappear in the 1980s. That was wrong. Reading long texts on a screen is not fun, so people don't do it. Computers make people read small parts of text. Some say this is a new way to tell stories. But many books are not read from start to finish, like religious texts and dictionaries. Computers don't encourage reading everything.
**The Office**
Charles walked into a tidy office. The carpet was clean, and the desk was neat. Kathleen was organizing files. She told Charles to use computers because there was too much paper. Charles admired the room and did not think about computers. He and Kathleen often talked about this. She didn't understand why he didn't like technology, even though he was good with computers. He wrote an important paper about computers because of her. She was very good with software and could make it do anything she wanted.

Lancelot's secretary shouted, "You don't take sugar, do you?" She knew he didn't because she had made him coffee many times. Lancelot was at the office more often now. He used to meet authors and playwrights for lunch, but now he was always busy and had trouble finding a parking spot. 
His secretary gave him a folder from a man in Los Angeles. It was about a book called "A World History of the Short" by Ian Cuthbert. Lancelot didn't want to see another summary of the book. Ian had been paid a lot of money to write it, but he hadn't finished it yet. 
Ian was once a very talented writer, but he was difficult to work with. He had been given many chances to write for magazines, but he never finished anything. Lancelot thought that asking Ian to write the book might have been a mistake.

'Breakfast in England
Breakfast is very important for health, say experts. But in the past, breakfast was not common in England. In medieval times, people did not often eat breakfast. Sometimes, travelers ate early before long trips, and sick people ate breakfast for health reasons. But most people did not eat breakfast unless they were kings or nobles.
In the 1500s, breakfast became more common. Some people think this is because there was more food. But there were also big changes in society. People started working for set hours, often starting very early. So, eating in the morning became necessary, not just for rich people.'

**Photography**
When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to show. This choice depends on their skills, ideas, and the culture around them. In this book, we will learn how these things change the style and meaning of a photo. We will also see how people look at and feel about photos. For example, when someone reads a newspaper, they see photos. But we can ask if the photo shows the real scene or the photographer's view. Is the moment in the photo important, or does it show something bigger about the world?
**More than a game**
For me, sport is more than just playing. The best people in sport believe in themselves a lot. You need to focus if you want to be the best. You have to work hard and not give up. Sport is tough, and you have to do it yourself. Sport teaches you to work hard and be strong, but it also shows you how to work with others. My sport lets you be good alone, but it is also a team game. Like in life, you can do well alone, but you must remember other people too. Sport has given me a lot, not just money. It has shown me new things and places. But you also have to give up some things for these good things.
**Tuning in**
Some memories stay very clear in our minds. For me, one special memory is from a night in California many years ago. I was awake, listening to a bird singing in a tree. I don't usually have trouble sleeping, but the bird's song was so beautiful that I stayed awake. The bird's music reminded me of jazz and Indian music. It felt like the bird was making up the music as it sang. I listened and enjoyed the music until I finally fell asleep.

People have always talked about birds. Birds are important to us. Paul Evans writes about this. A small brown bird is hitting the glass of a greenhouse. It is a wren. Some people think wrens bring messages or signs. Maybe it is just a bird stuck in the greenhouse. Both ideas can be true. Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In the past, people watched wrens to know if they would have good or bad luck. Today, we see wrens in pictures and decorations in many homes. Even if old beliefs are forgotten, people still like wrens. A forest without wrens feels empty. 
People have stories about many birds. These stories are old and show how people lived with nature. Sometimes, the way people see birds changes. For example, red kites were once common in London. They took food from people and were protected. Later, people thought they were pests, and they disappeared from many places. Now, red kites are protected again and are important for nature in Britain.
Our connection with birds is very old. Early humans watched birds to know about danger, weather, and food. Birds also made them think about dreams. Birds are important to us because they can fly, sing, and seem free. We like these things and they help us understand ourselves. Some people think these feelings are not important now, but they are still part of us. Birds show us how the environment is changing. In Britain, 30 bird species are in danger. This is sad because we lose not only birds but also culture. Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing are in poems and stories. Losing them is losing part of our culture.
Stories and legends about birds are important. They help us feel connected to birds. These stories are more powerful than scientific words. They make us feel and think about birds in a special way. Watching birds on TV or in our gardens is exciting. We cannot explain this excitement with science. Birds are interesting and make us wonder. The wren in the greenhouse is like a puzzle. It connects the past, present, and future with its song.

**Maps**
A map shows where things are on Earth. It uses distance and direction to do this. Long ago, people used time to talk about distance, like "a day's walk" or "a day's boat trip." This told more about how easy or hard it was to travel than the real distance. 
Direction is also important, but for most people, knowing "Where do I go?" and "How far is it?" was more important than exact direction. Because of this, people used written directions instead of maps for a long time. Even today, some maps, like train maps, do not show true directions.
Early maps used signs to show important places. These signs could be big or small to show how important the place was. Different maps used different signs, so it is important to know what each map's signs mean.
Making maps has become more accurate over time. People used science to help make better maps. For example, they used a compass to find direction. They also learned that the Earth is not a perfect circle, which helped make better maps.
Maps are used by many people now, like soldiers, historians, and geographers. They need maps for different reasons. Today, maps show many things, like weather, land use, and more. This has made map-making very important.
Map-making has not always improved quickly. Sometimes, old ideas stayed for a long time. Map makers needed better tools to make better maps. Sometimes, people just copied old maps because it was easier.
Maps are important because they show us how people thought in the past. Studying old maps is interesting and teaches us a lot.

'TIM RICE I went into a young man's nice room. The rest of the house was messy, but his room was very nice. It was like moving from a cheap seat to a fancy one on a plane. He had many records, a stereo player, and nice things like wine glasses and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He got a scholarship to study history at Oxford, but he had nine months free before starting. He wanted to be a famous composer like Richard Rodgers. I also had big dreams. I wanted to be a pop star for women, money, and fame. Andrew's dreams were very serious to him. When he asked me to write lyrics with him, I said yes. He played me some of his music, and it was very good. He needed someone to write words for his music. I didn't have much to show him, but I had written a song that was recorded by a pop group. We decided to meet again and write something together. I thought Andrew was very talented and determined. I didn't want to miss the chance to work with him. Even if we didn't become famous in musical theatre, we could try to make pop music together. The next day, I was back at my job training to be a lawyer. I still looked for bands needing a singer and wrote simple songs. I thought I would probably become a lawyer by the time I was twenty-five. But I wanted to see Andrew again. It would be fun to write musical lyrics with him. Andrew was interesting and liked good food and old buildings. He also liked a football team called Leyton Orient. He had an idea for a musical about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, who helped orphans. I wasn't very excited about the idea, but Andrew's music was good. He believed in his music, and it made me excited too. I didn't know much about musicals, but I wanted to try. I started writing lyrics for his songs. I even skipped work to write. I didn't know it then, but I was changing my career.'

**Language**  
Humans have a special skill. We can use language to talk to each other. Language is very important in our lives. If you see two or more people together, they will probably talk. Even when alone, people talk to themselves, their pets, or even plants. I think language is like an 'instinct'. This means people know how to talk naturally, like spiders know how to make webs. Spiders did not learn to make webs from school or special training.
**Climate and Weather**  
Climate and weather are made by the air around us. They are very important for animals and plants. Climate can change how a place looks. For example, warm and wet places have many plants and animals, like in a jungle. Cold and windy places have fewer living things. Weather changes every day and makes the climate. Air moves because the earth spins and because of the sun. The sun is a big reason why air moves.
**Coffee**  
I worked in a restaurant and had to serve drinks. I also had to make coffee, which was hard. In Melbourne, a restaurant needs good coffee to be popular. I learned a lot about making coffee and using the espresso machine. Making a good cappuccino is not easy. After one week, I thought I would only clean tables. But my boss was kind. He said, "Making coffee is both an art and a science. You need time to learn it."

**Art on TV**
Why does TV often not do well with shows about art? Painting and sculpture are good for the camera. The camera can show a whole artwork and then zoom in to see details. But, there are not many TV shows that show the joy and complexity of art. An example is Robert Hughes's show about American art, "American Visions." Hughes is a trusted critic with a strong personality. He had almost eight hours to show British viewers American art, which British galleries often ignore. I thought the show would focus on great art pieces. Instead, it was about how American history and culture are seen in its art and buildings.
**Dealing in Metals**
For 20 years, I worked as a metals dealer. I became known for taking risks. Metals are not as controlled as other markets. With luck, risk-taking, and market knowledge, you can make a lot of money. Risk is a big part of this business. This fits well with a free-market economy. But now, free-trade economists see that the market does not keep metal prices high. More minerals are being taken out, and raw material costs are going down. Adjusted for inflation, metal prices are about half of what they were 20 years ago. I was recently asked to check claims against a big company that benefits from cheap raw materials.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its small islands are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas. They go from Florida to Cuba. Each island is unique and has something special. To get around Abaco, you need a boat. If your room does not include a boat, don't worry. There are many ferries and water-taxis. You can also rent a boat. Sailing is very popular here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World.' The calm waters are great for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The islands and beaches stretch for 200 miles. At night, the lights of restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

Title: Make Your Own Bamboo Bike in the UK
At the Bamboo Bike Club in London, you can build your own bike. Engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan run the club. They help you make a custom bike frame over a fun weekend.
The workshop is in Hackney Wick, east London. It is the only place in the UK where you can build a bamboo bike. Bamboo is a new and exciting material for bikes. It has been used since 1894. But buying a bamboo bike can be expensive. James and Ian wanted to make it cheaper for everyone.
They spent years working on their idea in Wales. They wanted to sell bamboo bike frames. But then they decided to teach people how to make their own bikes instead. Now, they run the Bamboo Bike Club as a hobby. James works with wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer.
The course is affordable. You get a custom bike frame and a fun weekend of building. On the first day, you learn how to choose strong bamboo and make strong joints. You glue the bamboo tubes together. Metal tubes are used for parts that need extra strength, like the handlebars and wheel forks.
James and Ian help you with every step. They make sure everything is done right. If you make a mistake, you can try again. Bamboo is easy to work with, and you can choose how your bike looks.
On the second day, you wrap the joints with hemp and glue them. This makes the bike strong. You also add a waterproof coating. Then, you can add wheels, brakes, gears, and a seat.
The bamboo bike is strong and lasts a long time. Ian rides his bike to work every day, and James has tested his bike off-road. The bikes are very strong.
Bamboo bikes look different from metal bikes. They have a unique style. They are great for a relaxed ride. The bikes are light and smooth to ride. The cost is less than Â£500.

**Self-help Books**
Dione Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York. She found a book by Dr. John Gray, a pop psychologist. She thought it would be a bestseller, and she was right. Dr. Gray is now very rich, and Dione has her own company. Dr. Gray's book helps men and women talk to each other better. Many people in America want to improve their lives, and self-help books like this are very popular. These books are important for New York publishers. In Britain, many self-help books are also sold. Some books are not very good, but many are rejected because they are too similar to others. Editors look for books that can sell well. They ask questions like, "Is the author easy to promote?" and "Is the idea interesting to many people?" A good title is very important.
**Autobiographies**
An autobiography is a book about a person's life, written by that person. The writer and the reader should trust each other. The writer should tell the truth, but sometimes they don't. There are many reasons for this. Some things are too embarrassing to share. Some things might seem unimportant. Sometimes, writers make up stories to show the truth better. Some writers call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is not. Readers might think they read a true story, but it is fiction.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**
Detective stories became popular in the late 1800s and early 1900s. These stories show the problems in society. A crime in the story shows human desires like greed. Solving the crime helps society work well again. In Hammett's stories, society is not perfect. The detective and the criminal are similar. They understand each other. The detective is not completely good or bad. He is both a criminal and a competitor. Sometimes, the detective feels guilty, and sometimes he is very eager to catch the criminal.
**Science Writing**
Stephen Jay Gould is a famous science writer. I met him at a hotel to talk about writing. We both felt out of place there. Gould said that to write well, you need to understand the culture. Science is like its own world. Only scientists can explain it well. If you don't know the rules, it is hard to write about it. Gould believes you should not talk down to readers. You can use simple words, but you should not change the meaning. If readers feel you are treating them like children, they will not like your writing.

**Air-conditioning**
At Cannons Gym in London, it feels very cold because of the air-conditioning. The gym uses a lot of air-conditioning to stay cool during the hot summer. Sometimes, it feels as cold as the Arctic inside. Many places use too much air-conditioning. Instead, they could use other ways to stay cool, like using natural light and air, or having thick walls that keep heat out during the day and let it go at night. These ideas can help reduce the need for air-conditioning.
**Sundials**
Sundials are tools that tell time by the sun. People are interested in them again as we start a new millennium. A long time ago, sundials were important for keeping time. But when clocks and watches got better, sundials became just garden decorations. Now, people like them again. David Harber, who makes sundials, says they are special because they connect us to the planets. When a sundial starts working, it feels magical. They are calm and remind us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**
I once saw older women painting china cups with flowers. They were very good at it, and their hands were steady. I thought only very talented people could do this. But when I went to a china-painting class, it was different. The people there just wanted to have fun. Even the teacher did not want to paint quickly like a machine. Everyone was there to enjoy painting, not to be perfect.

Title: The Wrong Country
Uncle found a holiday for Keith and Dawne. It was a good price. They would fly from Gatwick Airport and stay twelve nights in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. When they booked the trip, the travel agent said they would be with a school group learning Italian.
But something went wrong. Instead of Venice, Keith and Dawne ended up in Switzerland at the Edelweiss Hotel, Room 212. At Gatwick, a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform checked their tickets and said everything was fine. On the plane, they heard people speaking with North of England accents. Keith thought maybe the Italian class was on another plane.
When they arrived, a woman with glasses said, "The coach will take us on." But the coach stopped at the hotel, and they were given rooms. They were tired and did not ask questions. The next morning, they realized they were staying there for the whole holiday. The receptionist said they could enjoy the lake and take a boat to Interlaken.
Keith told the receptionist there was a mistake. They were supposed to be in Venice. The receptionist said they were booked for twelve nights in Switzerland. Dawne described the travel agent who booked their trip, hoping to fix the mistake.
Mrs. Franks, a woman they saw at Gatwick, explained that many holidays have similar tickets. She laughed and said they couldn't end up in a wildlife park by mistake. Keith insisted they were not meant to be in Switzerland.
Mrs. Franks left, and Keith thought about what happened. An old couple, Mr. and Mrs. Nottage, said they slept well because of the fresh air. Keith and Dawne left the reception area. They realized their holiday was with elderly people, not what they planned. Uncle had said they needed a break from the elderly, but now they were on a tour with them.

'HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON American business leaders are learning from the explorer Ernest Shackleton. Eluned Price reports. Many people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and what he did. In America, people are just starting to learn about him. The Wall Street Journal called Shackleton 'an Antarctic explorer whose achievements were mostly unnoticed for most of the 20th century.' But now, Americans are very interested in him. Books about Shackleton's journey on the Endurance are being written, and a big exhibition is being prepared at the American Museum of Natural History. Columbia Tristar is also making a movie about Shackleton's life. Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They talk about his actions with admiration and learn lessons in leadership from him. Shackleton, with his warm sleeping bag and stove, is now a model for modern managers. Jim MacGregor, a manager in New York, has used Shackleton as a role model for years. His company helps with communication during business problems. For example, if a company's factory has an accident or if many workers lose their jobs. MacGregor says Shackleton is a good example because he was a strong leader and communicator. Shackleton made a brave decision to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole in 1908. This decision showed he cared about his men's lives. In a crisis, people want to know someone is in charge. Shackleton was always ready to take responsibility. His 1914 expedition became famous. His ship, the Endurance, was stuck in ice for nine months and then crushed. Shackleton told his men they would be safe if they trusted him and did their best. Shackleton planned carefully, kept his men informed, and asked for their opinions. He was flexible and ready to start again if needed. Shackleton believed an explorer needs optimism, endurance, and patience. MacGregor says it's important to wait and not rush to fix things. If a plan isn't working, don't be afraid to change it. Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he gave his gloves to a photographer who didn't have any. He also shared a biscuit when they were starving. Caroline Alexander, author of a book about the Endurance, says people today admire Shackleton's bravery and leadership. He represents the ideals we miss today.'

'Finding Food in Madagascar In the forests of Madagascar, there is an animal called the aye-aye. It lives like a woodpecker. Both the woodpecker and the aye-aye look for insects inside wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its teeth to make holes and its long, thin finger to get the insects. Scientists have learned how the aye-aye finds insects in the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson studied some aye-ayes at Duke University. He tested if they find insects by looking for signs on the wood. He gave them logs with holes. Some holes had insects, and some did not. The aye-ayes went to the holes with insects without needing to see signs. They did not use smell or sound to find the insects. They could find insects even if they were dead and quiet. Dr. Erickson found that aye-ayes tap the wood with their finger and listen with their big ears. They can hear if there is a space inside the wood. The aye-aye might be like a woodpecker in Madagascar, but there are also birds that look for insects in wood. The aye-aye is special because it is like a woodpecker, a bat, and a squirrel. Its teeth grow like a squirrel's, and it can open nuts with its finger.'

'Ordinary people, ordinary lives Many of us have photos of our grandparents, but do we know what their lives were like when they were young? We might hear stories from family, but they are often not complete. What will our grandchildren know about us? We think about writing things down but often don't do it. We might leave videos, but they are still just pictures. Hannah Renier has an idea: she writes life stories for other people. She makes a book with at least 20,000 words and pictures if needed. These books are about normal people, not famous ones. Hannah got this idea when she talked to her family and saw that many stories from the past were being lost. "At first, I didn't take it very seriously," she says. "But then I met people with interesting lives. They do it for their children or the future, but they also enjoy it." People feel safe to be honest with her. A 62-year-old man shared his life story, including hard times like his divorce. He did it for his family, hoping they could learn something. But he hasn't let his children read it yet. He wants them to read it after he is gone. He also saw patterns from his childhood that made him repeat mistakes. Hannah noticed this in others too. "Many people are influenced by their parents," she says. "Things parents said or did affect them for life. They might marry someone their parents liked or do the opposite to rebel." "Many people still feel sad about things with their parents, even 60 years later. They try to impress a parent who wasn't impressed." Hannah listens and writes their stories. "It's not for everyone to read, and I'm not there to be nosy. People sometimes tell me things and then say, 'I'm not sure if that should be in.' I include it, but they can take it out later. People want to be honest." "It's not about showing off. It's about remembering the past. We need to feel connected to our family history because families don't stay together as much now. People want to feel remembered." Each book takes about 30 hours of interviews. Hannah uses these to write the story, changing the order and explaining things. Modern tools help her make the book, except for the cover. You can choose the color and title. The book is for a private audience and is not about gossip. Hannah organizes the story well, and the book looks nice. It costs about Â£3,000, with extra copies at Â£25 each. She gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the cost stops many people. "I thought it would be cheaper," she says. "But the people I've worked with are often wealthy, like readers of certain magazines. They are the kind of people who used to have their portraits painted for their family."'

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has many copies of Greek and Roman sculptures. There are over 600 sculptures here. Remember, none of them are real. They are copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 1800s and early 1900s. The museum is in a special building with good natural light. The good thing about these copies is that you can see sculptures that are in different museums in Europe all together here. You can see many famous Greek and Roman sculptures in one afternoon.
**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a place for photography. It has darkrooms and a gallery with different photo exhibitions. They have courses and workshops for everyone, like a Beginner's Course and Master Classes with special photographers. Members can use the darkrooms. They also help young photographers aged 12 to 16 to learn more. They sell photo books and magazines and have many photo materials.
**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has a big collection of fossils, rocks, and minerals from all over the world. It also has Britain's oldest geological collection from Dr. John Woodward. There are nearly 10,000 special items in old cabinets. Adam Sedgwick was a professor who added many things to the museum. The collection is organized by time, so you can see how life on Earth changed. The new Whewell Gallery shows beautiful minerals and gems with labels explaining them.
**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
This collection has over 400,000 air photos taken by university staff over 45 years. The university has its own plane at Cambridge Airport and takes photos all over Great Britain. The photos show the landscape and human activity from old times to now. There is a small display in the entrance hall. You cannot borrow the photos, but you can buy copies. It usually takes about a month to get them.
**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is a unique tourist attraction. You can make wall hangings by rubbing over 100 different brass plates from tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The centre makes copies of the plates so the originals are safe. Brass plates were used as memorials in medieval Europe. Many were destroyed, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain. You can see many examples at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Being a Dad**
**A. The Theatre Director**  
I have had small children for 35 years, and I love it. I fed the baby this morning, and that is what being a dad means to me. I am lucky because my children and I like the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. We are close, and now that they are older, I am more like a friend to them. I do not believe in hitting. I have slapped my children in anger, but I do not think it is right. I try to be there for them if they need me. I do not call them to ask why they have not called me because it makes them feel guilty. My parents did that to me, and I do not want to do it to my children.
**B. The Advertising Executive**  
I was young, about 25, when my children were born. It was hard, but it also kept me young. As they grew up, they showed me new music and clothes. This helped me in my job. I missed some things when they were young, like concerts and sports days, because I was busy with work. But now I can take them on holidays. They like to come to parties and work events with me. They think my job is interesting.
**C. The Politician**  
My first child was born when I started my job in politics. My wife and I wanted to spend time with them, but my job is busy. I try to take my kids with me to work events on weekends. This way, they know what I do, and they do not feel like I am gone. More people in my job are bringing their kids to work now. We want to include our children in our lives.
**D. The Writer**  
My first marriage ended when my children, Kate and Bonnie, were young. I tried hard to stay close to them. My ex-wife and I even lived next to each other for a while, but it was confusing for the kids. Kate says I was always there for her, but I am not sure I was a good dad. I treated them like adults too soon. I wish I had been more organized. I still worry about my older daughters as much as my youngest. Your kids are always your kids.
**E. The TV Presenter**  
I was ready to have kids at 30. My wife and I had a nice house, so we thought, "Why not have a child?" Having my daughter Betty made me think about who I am. Having a child is special, but it also makes you just another parent. Sometimes it is hard, but one smile from her makes everything better. A baby's smile can make anyone happy.

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**
A. **Tamburlaine the Great**  
This play is about a strong warrior. It is very exciting and fast. Antony Sher plays the main role and does amazing things like jumping from a balcony. Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon.
B. **Women Laughing**  
This play is about two married couples talking in a garden. Later, it shows how illness affects people. It is a powerful story. Royal Court Theatre, London.
C. **Amphibians**  
This play is about the fishing industry in Ireland. It has interesting characters and funny moments. It ends with a big exciting scene. Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London.
D. **Murder by Misadventure**  
This is a traditional thriller about a 'perfect murder'. Two writers plan to kill each other. It has many clever twists. Whitehall Theatre, London.
E. **The Alchemist**  
This comedy is about tricksters in the 17th century. It is funny and well-acted. Barbican Theatre, London.
F. **The Madras House**  
This play is about fashion and women in the past. It is stylish and well-acted. Lyric Theatre, London.
G. **Dreams from a Summer House**  
This musical is like Beauty and the Beast but set in London. It has beautiful music and is about love. Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough.
H. **The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
This comedy by Shakespeare is not very good, but some actors are funny. Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon.
I. **The Voysey Inheritance**  
This play is about a lawyer who leaves a bad financial situation to his son. It is a great story. Apollo Theatre, Oxford.

**Hide and Seek by Yvonne Coppard**  
Emma and her friends are playing a game during their holiday. They watch a strange bookshop. Emma sees her Uncle Jim there. He tricks her into doing bad things and tries to make her leave her friends. Emma gets into danger and is locked in a scary house. The story shows that family and friends are important, but adults are not always good.
**Backtrack by Peter Hunt**  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, work together to find out about a train accident from 1915. Eight people died in the accident. They look at maps and old stories to understand what happened. The story is clever and makes you think a lot.
**Pigeon Summer by Ann Turnbull**  
Mary Dyer is a girl who loves her dad's racing pigeons. Her dad leaves to find work, so Mary takes care of the pigeons. She wins prizes even though her mom is upset. The story is set in 1930 and shows that being smart can mean different things.
**Yaxley's Cat by Robert Westall**  
Rose moves to a new house with her two kids to get away from her old life. They find a scary cat and strange things in the house. The people in the village do not like them. Rose's son is very serious, and the story is exciting and a bit scary.
**Someone's Mother is Missing by Harry Mazer**  
Sam is a boy who talks a lot and is not rich. His cousin Lisa is cool and comes from a rich family. When Lisa's life changes, Sam helps her. They learn about family and what is important. The story is funny and shows how they become close friends.
**Stanley's Aquarium by Barry Faville**  
Robbie works in a garden for an old man named Stanley. At first, Robbie likes Stanley, but then she finds out something strange about his aquarium. The story becomes exciting and shows how people can change.
**Dodger by Libby Gleeson**  
Mick has problems at home and school. The story is told through letters and notes. Mick feels bad about himself, but he gets better by acting in a school play. A kind teacher helps him. The story is sad but very good.

Title: Flying Without Gravity
Journalist Tom Mumford joins students testing ideas in weightlessness. 
The plane looked normal from the outside. It was a Boeing KC-135, made in 1964. But inside, it was different. The plane had a long white tunnel with lights on the walls. Most seats were gone, except a few at the back. Thirteen students from Europe and America sat there. They were excited and nervous.
For a year, these students competed to be on this flight. The European Space Agency asked for creative experiments to do in weightlessness. The best ideas won a place on this special flight. The plane would fly up and down like a roller-coaster. At the top of each curve, the plane and everything inside became weightless for a few seconds.
The plane took off smoothly. But soon, it climbed steeply. The engines were loud, and we felt strange. Then, the engines stopped, and we felt weightless. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence. It was hard to know which way was up or down.
After 10 seconds of falling, the pilot made the plane fly level again. Gravity returned, and some students fell to the floor. There were 30 curves in total, giving 10 minutes of weightlessness for experiments.
The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats land on their feet. A German team looked at how metal joins in space. Students from Utah State University tried to make solar sails from thin films. These sails could help satellites move using the sun's light.
After two hours, we felt a bit sick, but mostly excited. One student said, "It was unforgettable. I want to be an astronaut even more now."

**With the Trees, I Made a Home in New Zealand**
Jonathon Porritt is the author of "Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology."
I had a strange time in my life when I didn't have any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer from here, which is winter in New Zealand. So, I had nine winters in a row. I liked it because I enjoy winter.
My parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, "If you plant trees on it, you can have it." This way, we would always have a connection to New Zealand. My father grew up there, so it was special. They found land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land wasn't very good, but it was okay for planting trees.
I have always liked land. I spent a year in Australia working on farms, so planting trees sounded nice to me. I started planting in 1968, and by 1972, we had planted all 70 acres.
In 1968, it rained a lot in New Zealand. It was a happy time, even though it rained almost every day. I was often wet and cold. Every morning, I got ready to plant more trees. I had a helper who knew how to plant trees, which was good because I was new to it.
We used a planting bag to carry the trees. It was hard work, but I liked it. We had to make sure the lines of trees were straight. Once we lined up the poles, we planted the trees in a straight line. I enjoyed the hard work, and it made me fit. After a while, planting became easy, like a rhythm.
While planting, I thought a lot about life and nature. These thoughts have stayed with me. I have visited New Zealand four times since then to see the trees grow. It makes me happy to see them doing well.
I worry when I read about bad weather in New Zealand, but the trees are now 20 years old and healthy. In 1984, I took time off from teaching and went back to New Zealand alone for three months. I wrote my first book, "Seeing Green," there. I stayed in a small cabin with just a bed, table, and chair. I wrote in the mornings, pruned trees in the afternoons, and did research in the evenings.
I still feel a strong connection to that place. It is where I feel most connected to the earth.

**Bringing Up Badgers**
"What now?" I thought when a helper gave me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I have a farm in Somerset. We help orphaned animals. The noise from the box was strange. I looked inside and saw three small grey badger babies. They were about eight inches long. Their fur was soft, and they had black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger babies before. They are usually born between January and March and stay underground. If they lose their mother, they often die.
These three babies were found by builders. They accidentally broke into the badger home with their machines. The mother was dead, and the babies were still with her. The babies were healthy but cold and crying. I cleaned them and put them by the stove to warm up. There were two girls, Primrose and Bluebell, and one boy, Willow. I fed them with a syringe and wiped them with a warm cloth to help them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. Soon, they drank from a bottle and moved around a bit. They seemed happy with each other and a warm pad as a pretend "mom."
Three weeks later, Willow seemed tired but still ate. The next morning, he was dead. The vet said he had a lung infection. When feeding animals, they should not drink too fast, or liquid can go into their lungs. This happened to Willow, and he got sick. I was sad but kept caring for the others. Then, a farmer brought me another male badger baby. He was cold and hungry. We named him Willow II.
Willow II was hard to feed. I had to move the bottle around for him to drink. After a while, he learned to eat. By the end of April, the girls ate creamed rice and other foods. Willow II was messy with his food. I gave him a sausage, and he finally ate it. Soon, he ate other foods too.
At five months old, they ate cereals for breakfast, meat and vegetables for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, eggs, and seeds for dinner. Badgers usually eat earthworms, bugs, and small animals. My badgers were lucky because the summer was hot, and finding food was hard.
By August, the badgers became active at night. We walked in the orchard at dusk. They played and chased each other. Derek and I joined in, but he often got nipped. Other badgers came to our field looking for food. We were warned they might harm our badgers, so we made the pen safe.
The local press took pictures of us with the badgers. We started a project to build a home for them. With help, we made a sett with tunnels and a gate. It had three rooms, one with a glass side to see inside. The badgers explored it and soon moved in. A bus company helped with costs, and local firms gave materials.
One evening, the badgers moved into their new home. I checked on them and saw them sleeping. Now, I don't walk with them as much because they are awake late. Primrose visits sometimes, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to say hello before going out at night. This is their home now.

'Looking for True North - and the Man Behind Halley's Comet
Dr. Toby Clark works at the British Geological Survey. He wants to follow the journey of Sir Edmund Halley. Anjana Ahuja tells us more. Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for Halley's Comet. But he also did important work with compasses. He found out how to fix compass errors. This is called 'declination'. Declination is the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without it, sailors could not find their way on the ocean.
Halley was one of two men paid to do science in his time. He sailed to the Cape Verde Islands to study declination. But the trip stopped early because the crew did not listen. Halley tried again. This time, he went to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. In 1701, he made a map showing compass variations. This map helped sailors for over 100 years.
Dr. Clark wants to celebrate Halley's work. He plans to follow Halley's route on the ship Paramore. He needs to raise Â£70,000 first. Sir Vivian Fuchs, a famous explorer, is helping him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while in Antarctica. He read about Halley's life and work. Halley was a great scientist and explorer. He also helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book.
Dr. Clark's trip will also be scientific. He will take new measurements of the magnetic field. This will help update the Earth's magnetic field model. The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will give him tools. A Danish satellite will also take similar measurements. Dr. Clark hopes his work will fill in any missing data.
Halley's journey was the first big science trip on the sea. He was the first civilian naval captain for science. Dr. Clark has the skills for this trip. He spent two years in Antarctica and has sailed from Rio to England. He plans to finish the trip in four parts with different crews. Dr. Clark is very dedicated. He says, 'I am ready to spend eight months on this. Halley's life gives me a real purpose.'

**Peacock Tails and Why They Matter**
Every summer, peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tails to the female peacocks, called hens. This display is a mystery that puzzled Charles Darwin. He wondered why peacocks have such big, fancy tails in a world where animals need to be strong and fast to survive.
Darwin thought animals change over time through evolution. He said the strongest and smartest animals survive and have babies. But peacock tails seemed to be a problem because they are big and heavy. Darwin had an idea called "sexual selection." He thought female peacocks liked beautiful tails just because they looked nice.
Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different idea. He thought that if hens chose peacocks with fancy tails, there must be a good reason. Maybe these peacocks were healthier or better in some way.
Today, scientists like Marion Petrie study peacocks at Whipsnade to find answers. They want to know if hens really choose peacocks with the best tails and if these peacocks are better in other ways. They watch the peacocks and take pictures. They found that hens like peacocks with more eye-spots on their tails.
Another scientist, William Hamilton, thinks that peacocks with nice tails might be healthier and have fewer parasites. But it is hard to check this in the Whipsnade peacocks.
Marion Petrie is also looking at the babies of peacocks with nice tails to see if they grow faster and are healthier. If they are, it means hens choose mates for good reasons, like Wallace thought.
There is one more idea from a scientist named R A Fisher. He said that if a female picks a male with a nice tail, their children will also have nice tails. Over time, this could make peacock tails even fancier. This idea supports Darwin's thought that females might choose beauty just because they like it.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**
Tom Cunliffe says the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He did this with his boat, 'The Westerman'. 
In London, there is a big boat show with many new yachts. These yachts have new technology and are different from boats made 25 years ago. My boat is different. It is on a quiet creek on the south coast. It looks like it is 100 years old, but it was designed last year. Some people might think I am a romantic person because of this, but I am not sure. My boat uses old boat design ideas and new technology. 
New technology helps make boats, but it can also make sailing too easy. I think sailing should have some challenges. For example, I like my boat to have a coal stove for warmth and a nice place to sleep. But I also think sailors should sometimes work with the sails. 
Some boats have big cabins like a house, but I think a boat should feel like a boat. My old boat, Hirta, had no luxury. It had heavy sails, no electric water pump, no fridge, and no electronics. But it was a good boat to sail. 
Old boats need a lot of care. When I hurt my back, I had to sell Hirta. I wanted a new boat, so I built one. The Westerman is my new boat. The designer, Nigel Irens, first drew it on a napkin. Then he used a computer to make the design better. 
The Westerman is a great boat. It has crossed the North Atlantic and won races. It looks old but is made with new materials. It is strong and does not let water in. It feels like a real boat and shows that old ideas can still be good today.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**
Many people are visiting health farms and hotels with spa facilities. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.
**A. HENLOW GRANGE**
I went to Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room was very comfortable. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined many classes like yoga and body conditioning. The instructors are very good. I felt more flexible each day. They offer many treatments like aromatherapy, seaweed baths, and facials. The staff is very friendly and professional. Henlow is planning to add a new swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles or walk in the garden. I felt much better and full of energy after my stay. I want to visit again. This is a great place for a stressed working woman. Save Room 5 for me! - Marcella D'Argy Smith
**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**
Shrubland Hall is a calm and relaxing place. It has a beautiful library and conservatory. When you arrive, you get a medical check-up. They check your weight and blood pressure. I found out I had a shoulder problem, and they helped me with it. Each person gets a special diet. I lost weight but felt hungry and got a headache on the second day. My meals included grapefruit, salads, and fruit. You can have a massage or water therapy every other day. The extra treatments are not too expensive. - Liz Gregory
**C. CAREYS MANOR**
Careys Manor is not a health farm. It is a nice old manor with log fires and a big lounge. The food is very tasty, but not for people counting calories. They have a gym and a pool. There is also a spa bath, steam room, and sauna. They have a sports injury clinic. I got advice for my shoulder injury. Careys is comfortable and luxurious. You can also explore the countryside. - Beverly D'Silva
**D. CLIVEDEN**
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a swimming pool, and more. There are beautiful walks and gardens. The restaurant, Waldo's, has amazing food. I enjoyed a delicious meal and then used the gym to burn calories. I also had a facial and an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden has many fitness and beauty options. - Kay Letch
**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**
Springs Hydro has the best and worst carrot cake. It is delicious but has many calories. The aromatherapy massage is also great. I felt very relaxed and had a good night's sleep. The place is modern and well-run. They offer many treatments like manicures and facials. The guests are a mix of people, from football teams to friends. I would like to visit once a month. - Eve Cameron

**Natural Talents**
Humans and chimpanzees are very similar. We are more than 98% the same in our genes. This means that the things that make us different from animals are new. Our ability to make art and do other human things comes from a small part of our genes. 
Animals and humans are not so different. For example, chimpanzees use sticks as tools, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have simple language with sounds for different animals like 'leopard' or 'snake'. 
Art is one thing that seems special to humans. But our ancestors did not make art for a long time. The first clear human art, like cave paintings and statues, appeared about 35,000 years ago. 
People say human art is different because it is not useful, it is made for beauty, and it is learned, not instinctive. 
1. **Not Useful**: Human art does not help us survive or have children. For example, birds sing to find a mate, but human art is more about sharing thoughts and feelings.
2. **Made for Beauty**: Humans make art for pleasure. We do not know if birds enjoy their songs, but they sing mostly to find a mate.
3. **Learned, Not Instinctive**: Human art styles are learned. People in different places have different art styles, like songs in Tokyo and Paris. Birds, however, are born knowing their songs.
Human art changes quickly. For example, paintings from the 20th century look different from older paintings like the Mona Lisa. 
Interestingly, chimpanzees like Congo and Betsy also made paintings. They painted for fun, not for a purpose. Their art was shown in a London gallery in 1957, and many paintings were sold. This shows that the line between human and animal art is not always clear. Some human art is also made for personal satisfaction, not to communicate with others.

Title: A Big Adventure
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is a very dangerous place. Charles Blackmore crossed it and survived. There are not many big adventures left in the world. In the past, stories were about brave explorers. Now, you don't see many real-life heroes. But Charles Blackmore is one.
Charles Blackmore led a team across the Taklamakan Desert. The desert's name means "once entered you never come out," and people call it the Desert of Death. He talked about the dangers and excitement of the journey at his home.
The team had four British people, one American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. The camel handlers were actually truck drivers, which was a mistake that could have been very dangerous.
They traveled 1,200 kilometers across the desert. Charles Blackmore wrote a book about their journey. He left the Army after 14 years and wanted to do something different. His wife, Tina, was worried because no one had done this route before. It took them 59 days to cross the desert.
The team faced many problems: sickness, hot and cold weather, thirst, and losing some of their water. But they found water when they needed it most. They did not face the desert's famous sandstorms or very cold weather.
The sand got into everything, and climbing the high dunes was hard for them and the camels. They had no backup plan and were alone in the desert. Charles was worried about his physical strength but knew he had the mental strength.
At the end of the journey, they were tired but strong. Charles thought about his family while looking at the moon in the desert. He is proud of the adventure but values his family more.
Charles Blackmore still wants challenges and misses the adventure. He finds modern life too ordinary.

Susan Harr is tired of using too many gadgets. She decides to stop using some of them and finds joy in doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it makes life easier. But Susan thinks we depend too much on it. She had a bad experience with her broken word processor, which cost a lot to fix. This made her think gadgets might not be worth the trouble.
Susan starts using fewer gadgets at home. She wonders if technology really gives us more time or just makes us buy more gadgets. When her sewing machine broke, she decided to sew by hand. She enjoys sewing by hand because it is relaxing and she can take her sewing with her anywhere. She also likes listening to the radio or talking with family while sewing.
Susan got rid of her color TV and now uses a small black-and-white one. This makes her watch only what is important. She spends more time walking the dog, reading, and talking with family. She also enjoys washing dishes by hand and daydreaming.
Susan now looks around her house and thinks about other gadgets she can live without, like the freezer or microwave. She realizes she can save money by using fewer gadgets.

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker. He makes furniture like cupboards, tables, and bookcases. His workshop is in East London, under a railway arch. When you meet him, he seems like he is in a hurry. He is very busy because he has many orders. People know he makes good furniture, so they ask him to make things for them.
Hurst has been making furniture for ten years. He is very good at it and has a good reputation. He does not advertise, but people still find him. They know he makes beautiful furniture with simple designs. Hurst does not like furniture that is made quickly and not well. He wants his furniture to be perfect.
Hurst learned to make furniture by himself. He asked questions and learned from others. Most of his work is for people who want special furniture for their homes. Some people come back to him many times. He likes clients who know what they want.
Hurst is confident about his skills. He says he is naturally good at making things. But he also admires other good furniture makers. He does not like when people try to make furniture into art that is not useful. He believes furniture should be something people can use every day.
In the end, Hurst says, "I am only making furniture." This shows he is humble about his work.

'Why do we sleep? People sleep for about one-third of their lives. Sleep is very important, but we are not sure why. Scientists have three main ideas about why we sleep. The first idea is that sleep helps our body stay healthy. When we sleep, our body fixes itself and gets ready for the next day. The second idea is that sleep helps us learn. When we sleep, our brain organizes what we learned during the day. Without sleep, it is hard to learn new things. The third idea is that sleep gives us energy. We sleep to recharge, like a battery, so we have enough energy for the next day.'

**Eccentrics**
An eccentric is a person who acts differently from most people. They do not follow what is normal in society. But what is "normal"? Many of us have small, strange habits. Maybe we like to enter contests in newspapers, collect beer mats, or write letters to newspapers about many topics. Eccentricity means being unique.
Inside us, there are two forces. One is called individualism, which means being different. The other is conformity, which means being like everyone else. Most people want to be accepted and loved, so they choose conformity. They want to be part of a group and not stand out.
People with unusual hobbies or ideas often find others like them. They make clubs and have meetings to talk about their interests. They feel better when they are with others who understand them.
Sometimes, people want to show they are different. They might say, "I say what I think," or "You must take me as you find me." This is not eccentricity. It is just showing individuality.
Some people become famous by being different, like Bob Dylan, a singer. He said, "When you know what you want to do, keep doing it." But being different on purpose is not eccentricity. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they just are. They do not care what others think. They do things because it is who they are.
Eccentrics are not like people who play jokes, want attention, or hide from others. These people think a lot about society. Eccentrics do not. They live their lives in their own way.

**Natural Books**
We asked four nature experts to tell us about a book on wildlife that influenced them the most.
**A. Geoffrey Lean**
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have met many important people in this field. Barbara Ward, a small and frail woman, is the most important. She was very involved in environmental issues in Europe after the war. She wrote about her experiences and ideas in her books. As a young journalist, her work helped me understand the environment better. Her book, "The Home of Man," is about the fast growth of cities and the need for sustainable development. I think it is her most important book.
**B. Linda Bennett**
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can imagine the sounds and smells of a gull colony. This book explains how animals communicate. After reading it, watching a gull colony becomes more interesting. You can see how they work together. Niko Tinbergen was a scientist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. He worked with artist Eric Ennion to create this book. Ennion's paintings show the behavior of gulls with just a few lines and colors. This book is great for anyone who loves wildlife.
**C. Lee Durrell**
"My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell is the book that influenced me the most. It led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation. I first read it while doing research in Madagascar. I was having a hard time, but this book made me feel better. It shows a world full of animals, people, joy, and beauty. It reminds us that all living things are connected like a family. This is an important idea for everyone to understand.
**D. Bruce Pearson**
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library in 1966. I loved the 48 color pictures of birds by Eric Ennion. I already liked bird books and learned to identify birds during holidays. This book had more to offer. It had chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and birds in music, literature, and art. It helped me appreciate birds and nature in a broader way. The book showed me that my emotional and creative response to nature is as important as a scientific one. Since I was better at art than math or physics, this book opened a new path for me.

Title: Do Reviews Help Sell Books?
We asked five important British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said:
Publisher A: Reviews are very important for publishers. Many people buy books because of reviews. Both authors and publishers feel bad if there are no reviews. Publishers think that even bad reviews can help sell books because people want to see for themselves. Publishers like reviews that agree with their own thoughts about the book.
Publisher B: Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they want different things. Newspapers want to entertain readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed positively. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago. However, paperbacks often do not get enough attention. Reviews help people know about a book and can increase sales, especially if many reviews are positive.
Publisher C: Reviews are very important for us. We publish books by authors who are not very famous, so we need reviews to help sell our books. Good reviews are better than advertisements because they are honest. Reviews can help a book become popular, but they need help from other things like word-of-mouth and good marketing.
Publisher D: In the US, a review in the New York Times can make a book very popular. In Britain, it is different. Sometimes, it takes many years for people to notice a good writer. Some books sell well even without good reviews. It is hard to predict what will happen with reviews.
Publisher E: Publishers and writers want good reviews. But do they sell books? I published a book with great reviews, but it did not sell well because people felt they knew the book from the reviews. The name of the reviewer used to matter more. Now, it is more about the review's style and originality that makes people want to buy the book.

**Weathervane Maker**
Making weathervanes is a very old skill. It started in ancient Egypt. Today, Graham Smith makes weathervanes by hand in his workshop. He is one of the few people who do this in the country. Graham makes special designs for each customer. He says, "This way, I can make a unique gift." Many of his customers are women who buy gifts for their husbands. They want a special gift that shows the man's job or hobbies.
The most common weathervane design is a cockerel (a rooster). But Graham's first weathervane was a witch on a broomstick. He made it as a surprise gift for his wife. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them too. Graham saw that he could make many different designs. So, he started a weathervane business.
Before this, Graham worked as a precision engineer for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, decided to change roles. Liz went to work, and Graham stayed home to take care of their children and build his business. That was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. He likes the creative part of his work.
Graham has made over 100 original designs. He works carefully and shows the design to the customer before cutting it by hand. He also keeps traditional designs because people like them too. Graham says people like handmade things because they are different.
Graham does not want to make his business bigger. He wants to keep it as a small craft. He says, "I have found my place in the market. People love the unique designs." Weathervanes help people know the wind direction and weather changes. More people are moving to the countryside, and they want special things for their homes. This helps Graham's business.
Graham is very busy now. He sends weathervanes to customers all over the world, especially in America and Denmark. The price depends on how detailed the design is. His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. Graham can make a special gift for any occasion.

Title: Beginner Wins Big
Before it was published, "The Horse Whisperer" was a very popular book. It is the first book by British writer Nicholas Evans. He made a lot of money from it. Here, he talks about his ideas and success.
At the start of the year, things were not good for Nicholas Evans. He is a writer and producer. A movie he was working on, called "Life and Limb," was canceled. He was worried because he had not made money for two years. He needed money to pay the bank.
Instead of getting a job, Evans decided to go to America. He wanted to write his first book. He got the idea for the story from a man he met in Dartmoor. The man told him about a horse that changed from bad to good because of a "horse whisperer." Evans was interested and wanted to write a book about it.
He traveled across the US to learn about horses and the people who work with them. He felt alone and worried about money. He showed the first part of his book to a friend who was a book agent. The friend said it was "fine" and thought Evans might get $30,000 for it. Evans needed more money than that.
In October, Evans sent the first part of his book to publishers. Soon, his agent told him that someone offered $75,000 for the book. Evans was surprised. In one week, the book was sold for a lot of money in the UK and the US. It was a record for a first book. Big movie studios also wanted to make a film from it.
Evans was happy but did not want to write the movie script. He wanted to stay away from the movie business. He thought it was better to write another book.

'Bobby Fischer is trying to play chess again after 20 years away. Chess is now a game for young people. Bobby Fischer is playing against Boris Spassky. Bobby won the first game, but he is not as strong as he was in 1972. He is 49 years old and not in practice. Boris Spassky is even older. Chess has changed a lot in 20 years. Now, players focus on winning. They need to be smart and strong. Games are longer and harder. Young players have an advantage. Most top players are under 30. Computers are important in chess now. They help players prepare for games. Many players have teams to help them. Chess games can last up to eight hours. Players must stay focused. They use a chess clock to keep time. If they run out of time, they lose. The end of the game is very fast and exciting. Winning feels great, but losing is very hard. Chess tournaments last many days. Players must be ready every day. Bobby Fischer once said he only wanted to play chess. He left chess in 1972, which surprised many people. Now, he is back. If he wins, he will earn a lot of money. But if he wants to be the best again, it will be very hard.'

**Fame and Success**
**A. Nick Grosso**  
Nick Grosso is a writer in his early 30s. He wrote three plays that people really like. Now, he is making his first play, "Peaches," into a movie. He says, "It's a small movie, but we don't know how small. It won't cost more than 30 million pounds, but it could be as cheap as 30 pounds." Nick is very talented. Before writing "Peaches," he never saw or read a play. He says, "When I wrote the play, I didn't think it would be shown. It's set in a car. I wouldn't do that now because I know it's hard to do. I knew nothing back then." Nick left school at 16 but went back a year later. After finishing school, he joined the Young People's Theatre. He says, "I wanted to write for actors. I wanted people to hear my writing, not just read it. I met people like me there, and I enjoyed it a lot."
**B. Simon Pegg**  
Simon Pegg is a comedian who is 28 years old. He studied drama at Bristol University. Now, he is writing a TV comedy show and just finished a tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. Simon worked hard, even in university, performing in comedy clubs. He says, "University was very theoretical. It made me realize I liked comedy more than acting. People think comedy is hard, but if you have courage and good jokes, it's great to make people laugh." Simon worked with a comedy group called Funny Business. His work with Steve Coogan was very successful. Simon says, "Steve saw my show, and I was a big fan of his."
**C. Ciaran McMenamin**  
Ciaran McMenamin is 24 years old. He became famous as the lead in the TV series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." People liked it a lot, and now he can choose what he wants to do. He just finished school, but he always wanted to act. His mother encouraged him, and he acted in school plays and the Ulster Youth Theatre for four years. Ciaran says, "I used acting to avoid homework, but then I realized I loved it." Now, he waits for more success but says, "Fame is not about photos and interviews. It's about respect for good work."
**D. Neil Taylor**  
Neil Taylor is 25 years old and the lead singer of the pop band Matrix. They signed a deal for three albums with Domino Records. Neil and Rick Brown, the other half of Matrix, are expected to be very successful with their new song, "Chimera." Neil says, "The record company wants a big hit, but I will be happy if even two people buy it." Neil worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and tried to get into music for many years. He says, "I played student gigs for eight years and almost gave up. Then I met Rick Brown, and we formed Matrix." Neil hopes all his hard work will be worth it.
**E. Stephen Richards**
