Susan has always liked plants. She studied plants in school and collected wild flowers. She did not like garden flowers before because they looked fake to her. She liked wild flowers because they grew in hard places like rocks. Now, her garden has plants from faraway places like China and the Himalayas. She lets the garden grow freely, like a kind aunt who lets children play. Susan is busy with two art shows, so she hired another gardener. But she still likes to work in the garden because it helps her connect with her flowers.

Many trees in the Brackham area fell down during the big storms in March. The town lost two big lime trees in the market square. This changed how the town looked, and some people were not happy about it. One of these people was Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police. But during the storm, Pelham was very sick with bronchitis, so he did not notice the changes. 
Pelham was usually healthy, but he got very sick for the first time. He had a headache and chest pain. His wife, Molly, wanted him to see a doctor, but Pelham thought he was too important at work to take a break. This made him forget things and get angry easily. Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. Pelham was too weak to argue. The doctor gave him medicine, and Sergeant Lloyd took him home to Molly, who sent him to bed.
On Thursday morning, Molly told Pelham that the walnut tree in their garden had fallen. Pelham was too sick to understand. On Thursday night, he asked if the house was damaged. When he heard it was not, he was happy and went back to sleep. On Saturday, the medicine worked, and Pelham felt better. He got up and saw that the living room looked different without the walnut tree. 
Pelham's house was big with a nice garden. He liked the privacy the garden gave them. But now, without the tree, the living room was very bright, and the old furniture looked shabby. The view from the window was not nice anymore. The tall house next door, which the tree used to hide, was now visible. It had ugly purple bricks and many windows that seemed to watch them.
Pelham said to Molly, "Doesn't it look terrible?" But Molly was happy. She said, "I've been telling you we need a new sofa, no matter the cost."

Living in the Valley
We lived in our valley for sixteen months before we understood the dangers in the hills around us. One year, the storms came early, even before November ended. Before this, we felt safe in our valley with the hills around us. 
Soon, snow started to fall. In one day, it was 15 centimeters deep. It almost blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. On the hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed longer. The wind was very strong up there. In our valley, we only felt strong gusts of wind. The trees moved, but the branches did not break. We knew we had to be careful. The snow and wind were a problem, but they did not worry us too much. The river, called the Ryburn, was the real danger. It usually flowed gently, but it could be dangerous if the water from the hills was not controlled by dams.
The snow started to melt. Every day, we saw dark clouds over the hills. They warned us of more bad weather. We watched the river, which was getting fuller and wilder. The snow melted, and more rain came from the clouds. The reservoir in the hills was filling up and was almost too full. Then, for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. Water rushed over the dam and into the stream below. The river was very strong and fast near our home. It was deeper than we had ever seen it. For three days, we hoped it would not flood. Luckily, the dam held, and the water went down.
Before the dam was built, the river often flooded the villages nearby. Now, the dam controls the river, and everything is usually okay. We can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and feel safe in our home. The dam keeps us secure and safe.

Mark Adams is a film critic. He writes about movies for a newspaper called The Front Page. This was his first real job. Before this, he wrote reviews for books, movies, and radio. He met Tom Seaton, who was the first arts editor at The Front Page. Tom hired him. Tom wanted a team to review books, TV, theater, film, and radio. They would have lunch every week to choose what to review. It felt like a dream to Mark because it was a new newspaper, and he was part of it. He was surprised when he saw someone reading his review on the train. 
Tom's plan for a team of critics did not work out. People liked to know one critic for one subject, so Mark chose to write about films. Now, he writes one long article each week about one movie. He likes this way of working. He does not want to review every movie because it would be boring for him. 
Mark thinks people choose movies because of the stars, the ads, or the director. He does not think his reviews change people's minds about what movies to see. He does not feel he has to be 'right' about a movie. He just wants to share his opinion. He is not a judge and does not want to be one.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because "it's fun." A teenager who loves long sports WANTED: A sports-loving training partner for a triathlete, preferably a girl. Chance to work with a possible Olympic champion. Must like long-distance running (15km often), swimming in cold rivers, and cycling (100km is good). Must do all three without stopping. The triathlon is becoming a popular Olympic sport. Many people watch athletes swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and run 10km without stopping. It is exciting to watch, but why do athletes do it? And why does a smart 17-year-old girl give up everything for it? Melanie Sears has not learned to say things like "personal satisfaction" or "mental challenge" like other athletes. She says, "You swim 1500m, then get on your bike while still wet. You freeze. After cycling 40km, you run 10km, which is hard when you are tired. But it's fun and worth it." Melanie did her first triathlon at 14. "I won the junior section, but I was the only junior. It was easy, and I waved at my team-mates." She then entered the National Championships. She was fast at swimming and running but got lost cycling. "I cycled 20km too far and cried while running." But she did not give up. "Sometimes I want to stop because it hurts, but I am afraid if I stop once, I will stop again." Steve Trew, the sport's coach, admires her. "I tested her fitness. She worked so hard on the running machine that it threw her off. She gave it everything." Melanie was the top junior in the European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running but slower at cycling. That's why I'm working hard at it." She wants her parents to buy her a Â£2,000 bike for races. Her training makes her a bit lonely. "I don't have a social life. I'm not a party person. After swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I call and write to other girls in the team." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, about their times." Melanie has tried other events, like the triathlon "sprint," where you swim 750m, cycle 20km, and run 5km. She wants to try harder events. "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says. Funny, that.

'The Collectors Amanda Roy talks about collecting things and why many people like this hobby. I love collecting, and many adults do too. Collecting is fun and exciting. But remember, only collect things you love. People have collected things for a long time. Long ago, people collected pretty stones. They wore them as necklaces. Today, children still collect stones and seashells because they look nice. I have collected many things in my life, like flowers, pottery, and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. When I was six, I went to a school in a faraway place in England. It was cold and windy. My parents took me to a museum there. I loved the old things in the museum. Many people like collecting. Some people collect because it makes them feel in control. I collect because I enjoy it. A famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a 'room of wonders' with many interesting things. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. You don't need to be rich to collect. I have collected tulip bulbs and china cups. I once got a special tulip from another collector, but it was later stolen. I also collected 350 American rag dolls. I found them all over the USA. But my dolls were lost in a house fire. I was very sad. Collections can change owners. A silver spoon might have belonged to a king or a poet. This makes it special. Some old toys are now worth a lot of money if you kept the boxes. I threw mine away, so they are not worth much now.'

**My Job**
Four people talk about their jobs.
**Lisa - Exhibition Organizer at Science Museum**
I make temporary exhibitions. I plan and design them. I also tell people about the exhibitions. I read about the topic first. Then, I talk to important people to decide the main ideas. I choose what objects and pictures to show. I make sure people understand the exhibition. I plan fun activities and workshops. I work with engineers to keep the exhibition safe. Before it opens, I help make brochures to tell people about it.
**Janet - Teacher for London Taxi Drivers**
I start work at 7.30 a.m. I check the money first. Then, I make new maps for students. They learn routes for the taxi-driver test. By midday, 50 students are in school. They find the best way to go using maps. I help when they disagree. I give them a route to practice. I tell them to find another way if the road is closed. This helps them think better.
**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**
I live by the sea and work from home. I answer phone calls and make learning materials. I also set up training courses. Sometimes, I go to the main office, but mostly I am by the sea. I work with schools and take people out on boats. This helps them understand sea life better. I love my job because I care about the sea. But, I work for a charity, so we always need more money.
**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**
My job is different every day. I make sure our books meet what people want. We have 300 books. We keep high standards. We get letters from readers about maps. I talk with other publishers about new projects. I work with a great team. The hard part is too much paperwork. This means less time for fun tasks like making new products.

'Our Holiday in Ireland We always went to Ireland in June. Every year, the four of us spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. An English couple, the Malseeds, own the house. They made the house bigger, but they did it very nicely. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. 'How about this?' he said one evening and read the details. The summer before, we went to a hotel our friends liked, but we did not like it because the food was very bad. The four of us, Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and I, have played cards together for a long time. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school. He and Strafe went to school together, so we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live near the town where the Malseeds lived before moving to Ireland. We think it is a funny coincidence. 'How very nice,' Mrs. Malseed said, smiling when we arrived this year. She always knows when guests are coming, and she waits in the big hall that smells like flowers. 'Arthur, take the luggage up,' she told the old porter. 'Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium.' These are the names of the rooms for us. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of numbers. In winter, when it is quiet, she does things like that, and her husband fixes things. 'Well, well, well,' Mr. Malseed said, coming in from the kitchen. 'A hundred thousand welcomes,' he said in an Irish way. He smiled with his dark brown eyes, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and I felt like our holiday had really started. Nothing changed at Glencorn, everything was good. Kitty from the dining room came to say hello. 'You look younger every year, all four of you,' she said, making everyone laugh. Arthur took our bags to the rooms, carrying as much as he could and coming back for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but not too long because we were tired from the trip. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because in June, Glencorn Lodge is always full. From where we sat by the window, we could see some people walking on the lawns and others going to the seashore. In the morning, we would do the same: walk on the sand to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, then come back for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. We did this every year and loved the beautiful landscape.'

'Keeping the holiday-makers happy Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She works in Val d'Isere, France. Sarah is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex. She helps people who come to ski. She cooks and cleans in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah studied French and History of Art at university. She says being a chalet girl is fun for a year or two before starting a career. Sarah meets many people every week. Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks to work. The chalet can have up to 18 guests each week. Sarah eats her breakfast first. Then she makes breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans up. She makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms. She says cleaning is the hardest part of the job. By 11 a.m., Sarah goes skiing. She skis until 4.30 p.m. Sarah goes back to the chalet to make dinner. She takes a shower but does not sleep. Dinner is at 8 p.m. and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. Sarah cleans the kitchen after dinner. Sometimes she talks with the guests. Other times, the guests want to be alone. Sarah meets her friends at her chalet. They go out at 11 p.m. They visit places like Bananas and Dick's T-Bar. Sarah does not stay out late on Saturday. Sunday is her busiest day. She starts work early. Breakfast is ready by 7 a.m. for guests leaving. After they leave, Sarah cleans everything. She also goes shopping if needed. New guests arrive at 4.30 p.m. Sarah helps them with questions. She takes them to get boots or skis. Then she goes back to the chalet. It is time for dinner again. Sometimes Sarah is too tired and goes to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small girl with pale skin. She looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but said she was six years older. One day, she came to Seymour's factory. She wore overalls and big shoes, and her curly hair framed her pretty face. She was so small and young that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania. She was doing research on the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree.
A few times a year, someone would call or write to Seymour to ask if they could see his factory. Sometimes, he would help a student by answering questions or giving a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita was almost as small as the children from Marie's class. Years ago, Marie's class came to see how Seymour made gloves. Marie loved the laying-off table, where workers shaped and pressed gloves on hot brass hands. The hands were shiny and stood up from the table, looking flat. Marie called them 'pancake hands' because they were strange.
Rita asked, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' Seymour replied, 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand.' She took notes and asked more questions. Seymour liked that she was interested in every detail. He explained that the tannery was a contractor. They bought the material and made it ready for the factory. Seymour's grandfather and father worked in the tannery, and so did he for six months. He asked Rita if she had ever been inside a tannery. She said, 'Not yet.' Seymour offered to arrange a visit for her. He said tanneries were old places, and the work was hard. He told her that tanning was one of the oldest industries, with remains found in Turkey from 6,000 years ago.
Seymour said his father was the real expert on leather and could talk about gloves for days. He asked Rita if she had ever seen anything being made. She said she hadn't, except for her mother making a cake when she was a child. Seymour laughed. Rita was eager to learn, and she reminded him of Marie. Marie was smart and remembered everything she learned at school.
Seymour decided to show Rita the whole process of making gloves. He said, 'We're going to make you a pair of gloves, and you're going to watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?'

'Is it a hard job? Chris Arnot talks to four people with dream jobs to see if they are as great as they seem. A. Raquel Graham Raquel Graham calls from a taxi going to the airport. She can't meet us tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she travels a lot. Raquel loves her job and likes her boss. But she has one small problem - she doesn't like flying. 'On a nine-hour flight to California, I take sleeping pills to calm down,' she says. Her worst flight was on Concorde. 'It felt closed in with small windows.' When not flying, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She does paperwork, organizes the diary, attends meetings, and makes travel plans. She got the job by chance after meeting a pop group manager. She took secretarial classes at night. Five years later, she became a PA when her boss needed one. B. David Brown David Brown was an accountant and a golf caddy, a person who carries a golfer's bags. He liked being a caddy more because he loves golf. But there are downsides. He gets a small fee and a part of the winnings. He earns between Â£25,000 and Â£35,000, but spends a lot on travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman at 31. 'You don't just carry bags. You give advice and try to understand the course.' His accountancy skills got him a job as a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes golf statistics for TV commentators, magazines, and golfers. C. Martin Fern Martin Fern edits the 'Food and Drink' pages of a newspaper. One of his easy tasks is to try food at top restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? 'If people can pay, it's their choice,' he says. 'I'd rather spend Â£120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave.' His cooking talent got him a food column from a friend. At the time, he was a creative director at an ad agency. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. 'It meant earning 50% less,' he says. 'But it was a chance to turn my passion into a job.' He still cooks at home and stays fit by cycling to the tube station. D. Dick Prince 'I started writing children's stories 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, a popular children's writer in Britain. 'Before that, I loved words and wrote poems. Then I had an idea for a story. I was a farmer and knew about foxes killing chickens. So I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, my first published children's story.' Where do his ideas come from? 'It's not easy, I have to work on them,' he says. 'I usually work in the mornings. I'm not an early riser. After lunch, I type out my morning notes with one finger on an old typewriter, not a laptop. I get 50 to 100 letters a week, and I enjoy that part of being a writer. I try to answer them all, but now I have some help.'

'In the lumberyard by the lake, workers cut trees into boards for building. There was an old two-floor brick building there. Around it, there were big piles of soft sawdust. The sawdust looked like golden mountains and went all the way to the blue lake. One afternoon, Michael and his friends were bored. They climbed a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, 'I dare you to jump down,' and he jumped off the roof onto the sawdust. He laughed and said, 'I dare you all! You're all scared!' His friends looked down, scared, but then they jumped too. They laughed and felt happy. They lay on the sawdust, telling jokes. Then one friend said, 'Let's jump again.' They went back up and jumped again, but Michael stayed on the roof. His friends called, 'Come on, Mike. What's wrong?' Michael wanted to jump but was scared. He tried to count to ten and jump, but he couldn't. His friends laughed and got tired of waiting. They started to leave, shouting at him. Michael stayed on the roof, feeling sad and scared. He stayed there for almost an hour. The sun was setting, and his clothes were wet from sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes and slipped off the roof. He fell on the sawdust and lay there for a long time. The yard was quiet because the workers had gone home. Michael felt ashamed and walked home slowly. He was late for dinner. His stepmother was not happy and said, 'You should be home on time for dinner.' She was a kind woman with a little grey in her hair. Michael didn't listen to her. He was thinking about his friends laughing at him.'

'Career Advice Are you unhappy with your job and want to change it? Kitty Doherty has some advice. Many people who want to change jobs talk to a careers adviser. You will write a short history about yourself and take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you get a report with job ideas and training you might need. I tried Career Analysts, a big company that gives career advice. The test felt like a school exam. I was with about ten people, answering questions quickly. The tests had things like finding mistakes in lists and matching shapes. After the test, I talked to an adviser. He gave me a report with his thoughts and advice. I agreed with most of it, but I was sad to see I did not do well in science and technical tests. I am glad I did not become a nurse. But I was happy to hear I made the right choice with journalism. Changing your career does not always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager. Her friends told her to go to Career Analysts. 'Losing my job was a chance to think about my career,' says Donna. She found out she was good at design. But she had to think about the cost of learning design. Other ideas were to take a year off and work in the Far East. 'I used my skills to find a job better for me than insurance. Now I work in Public Relations. Career Analysts helped me see what I wanted to do,' she says. She told her friends about it, and they are happy too. Some people feel they need help to change jobs. Juliet Greene, 26, went to Career Counselling Services. She worked at a bank for six years and wanted a new challenge. She took tests and found out she liked sciences. She had four meetings with an adviser. After the meetings, she decided to study geology. She thinks the advice was worth the money. She is happier now. But career advice does not help everyone. Amanda Margetts, 24, is a sales representative. She wanted new job ideas. She got many ideas but did not like them because they paid less or needed a lot of training. She felt she did not learn anything new about herself. She thinks a friend could have given the same advice.'

Title: Fun at the Dentist's
If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dentist office in Glasgow, you will see bright paintings and a nice blue couch. Jerome says many people only go to the dentist when they have pain because they are scared. To help with this, he tries to make his office a place where people are not afraid. He does not wear a white coat because it can make people think of pain. Jerome believes going to the dentist should be relaxing and even fun.
Jerome uses virtual-reality headsets to help people relax. His office was the first in Britain to use them. During the first check-up, patients sit on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater animals while Jerome checks their teeth. Then, the headset shows a camera view inside their mouth. Many patients like this part of their visit.
The office smells nice, like oranges, not like a usual dentist's office. Jerome says smell is important because the usual dentist smell can make people nervous. The nice smell helps people feel calm.
Jerome is known as a fashionable dentist, but he takes his work seriously. He uses a special tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth, which is not painful if you are relaxed. Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn new dental techniques. He learned that making things easier for patients also makes it easier for the dentist.
When a patient arrives, Jerome offers them tea and asks what video they want to watch. The office feels more like a beauty salon than a regular dentist's office.

**Chocolate: A Sweet Story**
Chocolate comes from South America. Now, it is a big business all over the world. In the UK, people spend a lot of money on chocolate, especially at Easter. They also eat a lot of chocolate at Christmas. 
Chocolate is made from cacao beans. The cacao tree grows in warm places like Africa, South America, and Asia. The tree has big fruits with seeds inside. These seeds are cacao beans. When they are dry, we can make chocolate from them. 
A long time ago, the Aztecs used cacao beans as money. They also made a drink called xocoatl, which means 'bitter water'. The drink had spices and was used for special events. Later, the Spanish added cinnamon and sugar to make it taste better. 
In the 17th century, people in Europe started to drink chocolate. They melted chocolate blocks in hot water. In 1826, a man from the Netherlands made chocolate powder. In 1847, a company in England made the first chocolate bar. Later, a Swiss company added milk to make milk chocolate.
In the early 1900s, the British company Cadbury made a chocolate bar called Dairy Milk. It became very popular. Today, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week. 
Chocolate companies now make chocolate bars into ice cream, drinks, and desserts to keep people interested. 
Cacao farmers have a hard time because the price of cacao beans went down in the 1980s. Many farmers had to stop working. So, when you eat your next chocolate bar, think about the farmers who grow the cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**
Peter Cooke is 83 years old and very good at making art with shells. He wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers, but right now, he loves making beautiful things from shells. He has been doing this for ten years.
Peter shows his shell art in his apartment. He is very excited about his work and does not worry if people find it boring. He is charming, and his art is beautiful. He has shell ornaments above his fireplace. He says he does not mind if people do not buy them because he likes them so much. He did not plan to sell his art, but friends encouraged him to have an exhibition. Five years ago, he had an exhibition in London, and many pieces were sold. His second exhibition just opened, and his art is expensive, with some pieces costing PS2,000.
Peter says he does not set the prices. He believes no one else makes art like his. The gallery owner told him that people will want his art because he will stop making it one day. Peter wishes he started making shell art earlier in life because he could have made even more amazing things. Now, he is older and cannot work as much as before, but his art is still very special.
Peter's art is different from the shell items you find in seaside shops. He makes tiny, detailed boxes, pictures, and flowers from shells. He uses simple materials like cardboard, glue, and washing-up liquid. He says his art just happens naturally, but it is clear he pays a lot of attention to detail.
Peter travels to many places like France, Thailand, and Mexico to find shells. He only collects shells that are empty and does not harm living creatures. He says people walking on the beach break more shells than he collects. He believes his art makes the shells even more beautiful.

'The Schoolgirl Model Kira Langer is 15 years old. She is a model and sometimes she is on magazine covers. But she is also a student and studies for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw talks to her. 'Kira will be a little late,' the receptionist at the agency told me. 'Oh, fine,' I said. I was worried because I thought models were difficult and not very smart. And now she was late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. Maybe she went to the hairdresser's instead. If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and not want to talk to me. But when Kira came in, she was smiling and said sorry for being late. She was with her mother. Kira wore a simple black dress and trainers, not expensive clothes. She was friendly, tall, and pretty. Models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work, Kira explained. Her mother looked like a normal mum and was proud of Kira. Kira is surprised by her fame because it was not planned. Her older sister wanted her to join a model competition. 'She saw the competition and said I should try,' Kira remembers. 'I said no, but she sent some photos anyway.' When Kira found out she was a finalist, she was at school. Being a finalist made Kira confident, and she did well. She won the competition, and a model agency in London gave her work. Kira now has two lives: school and modeling. Her friends and teachers are proud of her. But some people at school are not nice. 'They say I think too much of myself.' This is hard for Kira because she is not like that. She says, 'They think I changed because I'm a model, but I'm just more confident now.' As a model, her social life is different. The agency can call anytime for a job. 'If my friends go out, I can't always join because I might have work. I can't make plans, but my friends understand.' Kira has a bright future in modeling. Not many people can say that before finishing school. I ask Kira what she would do if she wasn't a model. She thinks and says, 'I'd like to do what you're doing.'

Father and son look for gold
Terence and Chris Madden are a father and son team. They have traveled from cold Canada to hot Africa to find gold. Terence is an explorer, and Chris is a mineral expert. They think their mine on a Welsh mountain has a lot of gold. After ten years of digging, they believe they are close to finding gold worth five million dollars. Terence, who is 68 years old and from Liverpool, says they are finding more gold as they dig. They just need to dig a little more to find where the gold is.
The father and son started looking for gold after reading about gold in the 'Dolgellau gold belt' in Wales. They read old mining books and newspapers to find the best place to dig. They spent ten years getting permission to dig, taking earth samples, and cleaning the area. They dug out 150 tonnes of rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter hole. Now, they need more money to keep digging. They need someone to give them Â£50,000 to dig a little more and find the gold. Chris Madden says it is hard to find someone to give them money, but they have some people they can ask.
People in the area are talking about the dig. Dolgellau is a town that needs tourists, and people hope the gold will bring more visitors. Peter Woolven, who manages a hotel, says it would be good if more people come, but he hopes not too many people will dig in the hills.
The Welsh gold industry was big in the late 1880s, but now it is not. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, closed a month ago. But some people are still looking for gold. George Hall, another gold seeker, wants to dig a tunnel on the other side of the hill from the Maddens. Hall, who is 70 years old, says looking for gold is exciting and like finding hidden treasure. He hopes to be lucky this time.

**IN HOT WATER**
Rachel Mills is a scientist. She works at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel studies the sea and teaches at Southampton University. She goes underwater in a small steel vehicle, like a small car. She dives three kilometers down to study underwater volcanoes.
Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. Rachel can touch the two pilots. They cannot stand up or move much. They stay inside until someone opens the door. A dive lasts 16 hours. It takes three hours to go down, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up.
If there is a problem, they can press a panic button. A small escape vessel goes quickly to the surface. It is like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet.
Rachel was nervous the first time she went in the vehicle. She was on a ship with an instructor. He showed her what to do in an emergency. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place near the Canary Islands. There are many underwater volcanoes there. The Russian team was putting equipment there to study a volcano.
When Rachel is not at sea, she is at her office in Southampton. She loves teaching, but she also loves her research on "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes. Water comes out of them and looks like black smoke. It is very hot, 350 degrees.
Rachel was scared once when she was with an American team. There was a big explosion. She thought she would die, but they were okay. It was a big relief.
Rachel loves diving to the bottom of the ocean. She feels amazed when she sees the volcanoes. She studied them for three years. Seeing them for real was an amazing feeling.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired. My mind was tired of different timetables, money, and languages. "Never again," I said when I got home. But I said the same thing the next year. And the year after that. 
I just needed to buy one train ticket. Because I was under 25 years old, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. Sleeping in a train corridor is different from sleeping in a bed. The train's movement helps you sleep well. 
When you carry everything in a backpack, you travel simply. You might throw away socks that smell bad or books you finish reading. This is the Inter-Rail way. You don't need to think too much. Just have a ticket in your hand. 
This train ticket lets young people visit many countries quickly. On my first trip, my friends and I didn't know how special this ticket was. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our camp in France. But we wanted to keep traveling. There was always another country to see. And it didn't cost us more money.
We liked culture, but this was our first holiday without parents. We made our own plans and only saw easy-to-reach sights. We wanted to do something different, not follow a tour. I liked seeing the view from the train station. We just wanted to have fun. 
We were like other Inter-Railers. We shared train floors, food, water, money, and music. Traveling is exciting because you see new places. A city feels real when you see it with your own eyes. 
Seeing Europe helps you understand it better. Everyone knows about Europe, but it means more when you see it yourself. Other people's holiday photos are boring because you didn't see the place. 
The train trip is a personal experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail helps you see this. But for us, it took some time to understand.

'It is very disappointing to arrive at an airport in another country and find out your bags are not there. You might have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline finds your bags. Sometimes, you might be in a place with a different climate and have the wrong clothes. Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens to people who travel a lot. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and they cannot promise your bags will be on the same flight, especially if you change planes. 
Airlines ask you to check in early to make sure there is enough time for your bags to get on the plane. The shortest time to change flights is called Minimum Connecting Time (MCT), and it is also longer to help with bag transfers. Usually, this system works well. But extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights and cause baggage issues. Sometimes, human mistakes or accidents, like a torn label, can happen. These problems are worse at big airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. 
For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport had over 41 million passengers, and nine million changed planes. British Airways had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow. Even good airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. The chance of losing bags is higher at some airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing bags when passengers go to Latin America.
To avoid losing your bags, choose direct flights if you can and check in early. If you must change planes, try to use the same airline and allow more time between flights. Label your bags inside and out with your home and holiday addresses and include flight numbers. If your bags still go missing, talk to the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

'The Kingfisher
Charlie James is a wildlife photographer. He knows a lot about the kingfisher. The kingfisher is a beautiful blue-green bird. It lives near streams and rivers and eats fish. 
Old trees hang over the stream, making some parts dark and some parts light. The main colors are soft greens, browns, and yellows. The kingfisher flies very fast and straight, like a flash of light. It is small but very powerful.
Charlie loved kingfishers from a young age. He does not know exactly why he loves them so much. There are many stories about kingfishers. One story says a kingfisher was a moon goddess who became a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top became blue like the sky, and its bottom was burned by the sun. 
Kingfishers do not have blue color in their feathers. Their feathers reflect light, so they look blue or green. This is why they can change color when the light changes.
Many photographers love kingfishers. They are shy but can be watched from a hidden place. Charlie's first hiding place was an old blanket. He waited near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird came back and sat very close to him. It took him four years to take a good picture.
Charlie spent a lot of time by streams with kingfishers. He missed school to be with the birds. He did not do well in school, but people noticed his love for kingfishers. At 16, he worked for a nature magazine. Later, he became a wildlife film cameraman. 
Charlie wants to make a film about kingfishers with no talking, just beautiful pictures. He loves the simple beauty of the kingfisher. He likes to take pictures of their wings. Charlie has spent more than half his life with kingfishers, and he still loves them. His photos show his feelings, but there is more to his love for kingfishers than his work can show.'

**Conducting an Orchestra**
Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.
**A. Anne Manson**
Anne Manson is 30 years old. She asked to watch conductor Claudio Abbado in Vienna. She ended up helping him because his assistant was not there. She was not nervous. Anne works with a London opera company. She is also known in other European countries. The British Arts Council helped her with money. She has helped Abbado many times now.
**B. Andrew Constantine**
Andrew Constantine is 31 years old. He says the hardest part of being a conductor is getting the right chances. He won a big competition in 1991 after trying two times before. The competition gave him many chances to perform. He worked with a famous conductor. He hopes people will not only remember him for the competition. The English Chamber Orchestra invited him back after the competition. This is important for his career.
**C. Wasfi Kani**
Wasfi Kani started Pimlico Opera. She likes the long practice time for opera. She started conducting in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became professional. She learned a lot from Sian Edwards. Sian was the same size as her, which helped her learn. Wasfi likes the complex nature of opera. There are many arguments and singers to think about.
**D. Roger Vignoles**
Roger Vignoles is 48 years old. Conducting was a surprise for him, but he likes it. He was a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's Agrippina from the piano. It was easier than he thought. He knew the music well. People respect him as a musician. He learns from every experience. He will try anything to see what he likes.
**E. Wayne Marshall**
Wayne Marshall is 32 years old. In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed him. Wayne soon conducted a musical in London. It was hard at first. Some musicians were not serious. He was firm with them. He gave clear directions. He never studied conducting formally. No book tells you how to conduct. People have been kind to him. He is determined and knows what he likes.

**Theme Parks in Britain**
If you want to take children to a theme park, there are many to choose from in Britain. We asked five families to try the best ones.
**Fun Island - The Burns Family**
Last year, we went to a big theme park in the US. We thought Fun Island might not be as exciting, but we liked it. The park is good for young children, so our three-year-old had fun. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was great. For older kids, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were tired, but the kids wanted to stay. The park could look nicer, but the staff are very helpful, and it is clean and safe.
**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**
We had never been to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, with small famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars. We stayed for six hours and liked the places to rest. The park looks nice, and the staff are friendly. There is something for everyone, even adults.
**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**
After seven hours, we still had more to see. The kids loved the Big Top Circus with a trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and the girls were scared but liked it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don't. Toy Land is fun for younger kids. The new ride, Fear Factor, was too big for our kids. The park is well designed, and even waiting in line is not boring. It is very clean, and the staff are great. A staff member helped us on a ride.
**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**
We arrived at 1 p.m. and were sad the park closed at 5 p.m. This park is good for younger kids because the rides are not too scary. I am scared of rides, but I had fun. We loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then gets exciting. We waited 30 minutes for Lightning River, and it was over quickly. I didn't go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun. If the kids were older, they might find it boring, but they loved it.
**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**
The park says there is 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we agree. The Rocket, Europe's tallest roller-coaster, is very scary. Ben thought it was the scariest ride, but Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down, was worse! There are many rides, and the older kids went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides but liked the Long Slide. The staff were sometimes nice, but not always. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We couldn't leave early because the kids were having too much fun.

**Running a Business in the Countryside: Five Women's Stories**
**A. Christine Hogan**  
Christine Hogan runs a computer design business. She makes over Â£200,000 a year and has four workers. She moved from London to the countryside with her husband and kids. She wanted a job she could do at home. Christine used to work with computers, so her husband suggested starting a computer design business. It was hard at first and needed a lot of money. She is careful with money and tells the bank if she might spend too much. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evening. Her business is small, and local people come to pick up their work.
**B. Maggy Sasanow**  
Maggy Sasanow designs greeting cards from home. She studied art and wanted to work in a museum, but there were no jobs like that in the countryside. So, she started her own business and makes 50 different cards. She sells them to museums. Maggy works in a big room at home. She doesn't advertise; people hear about her from others. She is cheaper than other artists, so people send her work from London. She misses talking to other people about ideas, but she likes being independent.
**C. Delia Turner**  
Delia Turner makes curtains. Her business has had good and bad times. She started eight years ago, and her business grew quickly. She used to have six workers, but she had to let them go because the economy got worse. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband and other women who work from their homes. She has to lower her prices sometimes and look for new chances.
**D. Tessa Strickland**  
Tessa Strickland runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside because London was too expensive and she loves the country. She likes working when she wants. Most of her money comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so she takes calls at odd hours. It is hard to stop working sometimes. She publishes children's books from different cultures and works with authors and artists. She felt alone at first because she used to work in London.
**E. Meg Rivers**  
Meg Rivers runs a cake business and a shop. She makes Â£250,000 a year and has six workers. She started at home ten years ago. Meg is interested in health, so she made fruit cakes with good flour and eggs. Friends and family liked them, and soon she was sending cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building for her business. Now, she has a baker, an assistant, and a cake decorator. Meg doesn't bake anymore; she manages the business. The hardest part has been money because she didn't have much to start with.

Meet the Amazing Watkins Family
The Watkins family is special. The sons, Paul and Huw, are musicians and composers. Their dad, John, makes musical instruments. 
John and Hetty Watkins are from South Wales. When their son Paul was ten, he needed a cello. Cellos were very expensive, so John decided to make one himself. He found a school nearby that taught instrument making. He went to classes once a week for three years. After making some violins and violas, John made his first cello for Paul. It was very good. Later, he made another cello for Paul, which Paul used for many years.
John stopped teaching and now makes violins full-time. He makes about twelve violins a year. He even sold one to a famous American musician, Jaime Laredo.
Paul and Huw started playing music when they were young. Paul first played the piano, then he wanted to play the cello. He liked the cello player in his dad's music group. Paul learned the cello and became very good. He won a big music competition and played in the BBC Symphony Orchestra. Now, he plays a very old cello from the Royal Academy of Music.
Huw, the younger brother, plays the piano and writes music. He is also doing well in music.
The Watkins family is very busy with music. Paul will be on TV playing the cello, and Huw's music will be played in London. Their parents, John and Hetty, are very proud and support their sons in their music careers.

Looking after the countryside
THE NATIONAL TRUST
The National Trust is a group that takes care of the countryside in Britain. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust. 
Gareth says a warden needs common sense. He also needs to be good with people because he talks to farmers, visitors, and builders. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm. Many people wanted the warden job, but Gareth got it because he knows the area well and has farming experience, even though he did not have special training.
Gareth still helps on his parents' farm, so he understands farmers' problems. He is also strong enough to do hard work like building fences and planting trees. Since working with the Trust, Gareth has learned more about taking care of nature. He remembers collecting flowers and bird nests as a child and now sees how farming has changed the countryside. He says it is not the farmers' fault because they followed government rules.
At first, farmers and people who care about nature did not agree. Now, they talk and understand each other better. Gareth's job is to make sure work is done well and cheaply. He likes seeing projects finished, but he also spends time on paperwork.
Gareth loves his job, even though he is always working. He enjoys talking to most people, but some visitors can be rude. He says being nice to them is hard. If you have common sense and like working outside, you might want to be a warden like Gareth. But there might not be a job on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!

'The Netball Captain
In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain. Kendra Slowinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. I asked her, 'Don't people look at you strangely?' She said, 'I focus on my movements and my feet, so I don't see much else. I might see cars slow down, but that's all.'
Kendra says, 'My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships.' She follows a strict plan to be very fit. These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries playing. 'We will have support from people at home, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to make netball more popular here. People will expect us to play well.'
Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'We have always beaten them, but they are good to play. They have a lot of skill.' The England team is ranked fourth in the world. But the World Championships will be hard. 'You have to play every day, with no rest. You only have one chance to win,' says Kendra.
In the fifteen years she has played at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive. 'You train to win,' says Kendra. 'But after the game, we are all friendly.'
Netball is now more scientific about fitness. 'We must think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. 'As captain, I need a strong mind and must lead by example. I support and encourage my team.'
'From the start, my netball career was planned,' she says. 'I decided this competition would be my last as a player.' She might coach young players in the future, but now she focuses on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.'

**Specialist Music Schools**
What do you do if your child is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them. Some parents might not see their child's talent until the child becomes upset or difficult. Regular schools are good for children who are smart in subjects like math or science, but musically talented children need special help. Regular schools might not have this help, especially if music is not important there.
Specialist music schools can help these children. In Britain, there are five music schools for children aged seven to eighteen. These schools help children become better at music with the help of professional musicians. Children spend a lot of time on music activities like lessons, playing in groups, singing, and learning music theory. They also practice a lot in special rooms. They study important subjects like English and math, but not as many subjects as in regular schools.
These music schools are private, and classes are small. Most children live at the school, which means they stay there all the time. This can be expensive, costing between Â£12,000 and Â£17,000 a year. Schools try to help parents with scholarships if needed. Some parents do not want their young children to live away from home. School directors say they want to help children grow into well-rounded people.
There are some problems. Being away from home can be stressful for young children. Some children might lose interest in music as they grow older. Schools watch the children closely and help them if needed. Some students feel they do not learn enough other subjects. Many musically talented children are also smart and want to learn more.
It might be better to wait until the child is older and can decide for themselves about going to a music school. Children who are good at both music and school subjects might do well in a regular school with a good music program. They can also take music lessons on weekends at music colleges, but this is not possible for families who live far from big cities.

Susan Shepherd is an artist. She is famous for painting flowers. Her house has a big garden with many flowers. She likes tulips and poppies the most. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. The garden looks nice because of the colors and shapes. The people who lived there before Susan loved gardening. They left many plants for her. Susan also got a gardener named Danny. She says, "It was really his garden." They worked well together. At first, Danny did not like some of Susan's ideas. But when she said she wanted to paint the flowers, he understood.
Susan likes to paint one flower at a time. She sometimes paints a group of flowers. Usually, she picks flowers and takes them to her studio. She paints one flower, which can take a few days. Then she adds another flower to the painting. Sometimes, it takes years to finish a painting. Spring and early summer are her busiest times. Tulips and poppies bloom then. Susan finds it interesting to watch flowers change. Tulips, for example, change shape in water. At first, they look boring, but then they twist and turn.
Susan has always liked plants. She studied plants in school and collected wild flowers. She did not like garden flowers before. She thought they looked fake. She liked wild flowers because they grew in hard places. Now, her garden has plants from faraway places like China. She lets the garden grow freely, like a kind aunt with children. Susan is busy with two art shows. She has a lot of flowers to paint. She hired another gardener to help. But she knows she must work in the garden to stay connected to her art.

Title: Sarah's Busy Day as a Chalet Girl
Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is 24 years old and works as a chalet girl in Val d'IsÃ¨re, France. She helps people who come to ski by cooking and cleaning in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah studied French and History of Art at university. She says being a chalet girl is fun and a good way to meet new people before starting a serious job.
Sarah wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks to the chalet. She makes breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, she cleans the rooms or prepares afternoon tea for the guests. By 11 a.m., Sarah goes skiing until about 4:30 p.m.
In the evening, Sarah returns to the chalet to make dinner. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and she finishes by 10 p.m. After cleaning up, she sometimes talks with the guests or leaves them alone. Good guests make her week better, but sometimes things don't go as well.
Sarah lives with friends and goes out with them at night, but she doesn't stay out late on Saturdays. Sunday is her busiest day. She starts work early to make breakfast by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she cleans the chalet and gets ready for new guests. She also helps them with ski equipment if needed. After dinner, Sarah might chat with friends or go to bed early if she is tired.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**
Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper. She spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. She usually wears a uniform, but she had to choose clothes for this day. First, she went to a photo studio, then to see new clothes, all before lunch. The zoo is quiet and calm, but at the magazine, she was very busy. Some people at the magazine were stressed, but her job is not stressful. In the afternoon, she watched a fashion photo shoot. She thought it was funny because she usually cleans cages or handles rats. Mandie likes to see how magazines work, but she loves her job at the zoo and wants to stay there.
Alice Cutler is a fashion assistant at Marie Claire. She spent a day at London Zoo. She wore leather boots and dark blue trousers, but the zoo gave her a green shirt to wear. She got very dirty. She touched an elephant and thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, she smelled bad but had a great day. She thinks she might work with elephants in Africa when she stops working in fashion.
Karen Hodson is a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital. She spent a day with the TV gardening show Ground Force. She was excited to meet the team. Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was very nice. She liked being outside because she sometimes doesn't see daylight at her job. It was hard work but fun. She thought she was strong, but the team was stronger. Gardening was harder than she thought. She likes her job as a nurse and doesn't want to change.
Charlie Dimmock is a gardener on the TV show Ground Force. She worked at Hammersmith Hospital for a day. She made beds and gave out medicine. She thought she might faint, but she was okay. The nurses were very friendly. Her job felt less important than nursing. Her day at the hospital was not easy, but she felt good about it.
Lucy Harvey is a personal trainer. She spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. She wore a uniform and felt different. People looked up to her. Before the flight, she learned about safety and what to do if someone got sick. On the flight to Paris, she gave out magazines. People stared at her, and she felt shy. On the way back, there were 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. She wished she was back in the gym.
Sonia McDermott is an air hostess with Ryanair. She spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. She was worried because she doesn't exercise. She was surprised at how much attention trainers give to one person. In her job, she meets many passengers every day. At lunch, she saw that trainers don't always eat very healthy, but they drink a lot of water. She doesn't want to change her job, but she wants to join a gym and be healthier.

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Train Memories**
**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I love the south of France and visit often. There is a train from Cannes that goes along the coast to Italy. The views of the sea are amazing. It is beautiful in any weather or season. You can also see nice gardens and houses. The people on the train are fun, with tourists and locals enjoying the trip.
**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have taken many train trips, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express in Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip to the Kruger National Park. I was too young and stayed with my aunt. My first real train station was London Waterloo, and it amazed me.
**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I love the Blue Train. My husband and I took it on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress. I loved it and now always wear pink. The trip through France and up the Nile was perfect after our wedding.
**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were writing articles on a world trip and had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express train. The schedule was not fixed, and the driver waited for people. Many people climbed onto the train, even on the roof. At night, the views were like a dream.
**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
I did not see many trains as a child in Singapore and Cyprus. As a teenager, I made a film in Yorkshire with a railway. The old train line was kept by volunteers. I loved steam trains. We rode the train often, and when I returned last year, everything was the same, even the gas lights!

'Do you want to get your story published? Our expert, Margaret Stubbs, can help you. Many people ask, 'I wrote a story. Who should I send it to?' First, you need to learn about publishers and practice writing. Selling your writing needs knowledge about the 'writing world'. You must know the market for your writing. The best way is to read a lot. Visit your library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading helps you see what publishers want. Remember, things change. New magazines come, and editors change jobs. Publishers always want new writers. You must give them what they want. If you want to write love stories, find magazines that publish them. Get recent copies and see what stories they like. Know who the readers are. Editors want to please their readers. Writers often ask, 'My story was rejected. Am I wasting my time?' I never say stop trying. But maybe the story is not ready. Many new writers send their work too soon. If you wrote only one story, it might not get published. Success usually comes after many tries. When you send your work, keep writing more stories. Write ten or twenty more. Each story will be better. You will feel more like a writer. Don't throw away your stories. Improve them. Don't show your work to others too soon. Remember, every writer gets rejected before they succeed. Do everything to become a better writer. Look for a writing course or join a writers' group. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

On the last day of a bad year, I was at the Baltimore train station. I was waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were many people there. The station did not feel nice and clean like usual. 
Old couples with matching bags sat on the benches. Many college students sat on the floor with their bags. A man with grey hair was talking to different people. He looked rich. He wore a nice sweater and a soft coat. 
He asked a woman if she was going to Philadelphia. Then he asked a girl near me. She had long blond hair. I thought I might like to talk to her. The man asked, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said, "No, I am going to New York." He said, "Thanks, anyway," and moved on.
I was curious now. I heard him ask an old lady, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said, "Wilmington." He did not say anything and moved on. I was going to Philadelphia, but he did not ask me. Maybe he thought I looked unreliable.
He looked worried. He asked a woman reading a book, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said, "Yes, I am." He asked her for a favor. I pretended to look at my watch, but I was listening. 
The man said his daughter was flying out for a study year abroad. She forgot her passport. She called from the Philadelphia station. He asked the woman to take the passport to his daughter. 
The woman asked, "Why don't you go yourself?" He said, "I can't leave my wife alone. She is in a wheelchair." 
I thought this was a strange excuse. The man had a padded envelope, not a plain one. It looked stapled shut. I thought, "Be careful, lady."

**Gary and Me**
John Moore owns a restaurant. He talks about his son, Gary, who is a famous TV chef.
I think everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking. My chance was to run a restaurant. When I found out about the restaurant, I went to see it quickly. It was in bad shape, but it was just what I wanted. 
Running the restaurant made me think of my childhood. I remember my mom working in a factory. I was sad because I was alone. So, I wanted to have time for family. My wife took care of the kids and did the money work, while I ran the restaurant. We lived above the restaurant. We always ate meals together. This was good for our kids, Gary and Joe. They are both very confident. They talked to our customers from a young age. This helped them a lot.
Gary was a lively child. When he was seven, he jumped into the bath like a pool and got hurt. When he was older, he worked for pocket money. He did small jobs and by ten, he worked in the kitchen every weekend. He had a lot of money at school. He was disciplined. He woke up early, even before me. 
In a family business, everyone helps. It was nice to see Gary helping. Gary was not very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By 15, he was as good as the adults. Sometimes, he was in charge. He made over a hundred meals. I knew he would work in cooking. When he needed work experience for school, I sent him to a friend's restaurant.
Gary started playing drums and has a band now. I wonder what will happen to his cooking if his music becomes popular. I told Gary, "If you try to do two things, you might not succeed in either. Focus on one thing." He understood when I said, "If you want to succeed, do it by 30. After that, it might be too late."
Gary went to cooking school at 17. On his first day, he finished his work very fast. He even helped others. We are all surprised by how successful Gary's TV show is. I am very proud of him. I always told him to work hard because nothing is free. He took his chance and worked hard. When you talk to your kids, if they remember even a little, you should be happy. Gary listened to me sometimes, I think.

Finding a good apartment in Dublin that you can afford is very hard. The best way is to know someone who knows someone leaving a place. But if you are new in Dublin, like Jo, you don't know anyone. Jo had to stay in a hostel and look for a place. Dublin was a big unknown for her. She didn't think much about why she was going there. Everyone from her school wanted to leave their small town and see more of the world. Some of her classmates went to nearby towns, but Jo was the only one going to Dublin. 
Jo's mother thought it would be good for her to stay in the hostel because it was safe. Her father hoped it was warm because hostels are often cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a week. Jo didn't know they were talking about her as she looked at an ad for a flat in Ringsend. It said, "Own room, own TV, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to her work at the post office and seemed perfect. She hoped it was nice and not too expensive.
There wasn't a long line for this flat because it was more like "Third Girl Wanted" than "Flat to Let." Jo worried it might be too fancy because it had its own TV, but the house looked normal. It was a red-brick house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A girl with a college scarf was leaving and said, "Desperate place. They're both awful." Jo kept going up the stairs.
A girl named Nessa, wearing a T-shirt with her name on it, greeted Jo. Nessa didn't like the girl who just left. She said the girl acted snobby. Pauline, the other girl, wore a very colorful shirt and had bright hair. Jo was surprised because Pauline was a punk. Jo introduced herself and said she worked at the post office. Nessa offered Jo a mug of tea. They had mugs with their names on them, and one said "Other." Nessa said they would put Jo's name on it if she stayed.

'Dolphins and Their Problems People love dolphins. We like to see them at the beach, in movies, and on TV. But dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about how dolphins are disappearing. Dolphins are special to us. They are smart, understand our feelings, and make us dream of freedom in the sea. TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest make us love them more. But these shows do not show the real problems dolphins face in dirty and overfished seas. In the North Sea, many dolphins called harbour porpoises are gone. We think 89,000 are missing. You might think dolphins are safe and protected, but they are not. This could be a big problem for wildlife. There are 40 kinds of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, the most common are striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and harbour porpoises. Striped and common dolphins live far in the sea. We see them in small groups near ships, but we do not know much about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are friendly and were seen in places like the Thames River in Britain. Now, they are only in a few places in Scotland and Wales. They have skin injuries, which means they are stressed. It is hard to know why there are fewer dolphins. Overfishing is a big problem. It takes away fish, which dolphins need to eat. Dolphins can also get caught in fishing nets. These nets are hard for dolphins to see. Many dead dolphins have been found on beaches in France and Cornwall. They had marks and cuts from nets. Waste in the sea is also bad for dolphins. Poisons like pesticides can build up in their bodies. Mother dolphins can pass these poisons to their babies through milk. One baby dolphin died from poisoned milk. Noise from ships and oil wells is another problem. Dolphins use sound to understand their world. Noise in the sea is louder than in the air and can disturb dolphins. We do not know how this affects them yet.'

**GETTING FIT**
Exercise is very important for your mind and body. It helps you feel good when life is busy and stressful. Exercise is good for you, and there are many reasons to do it.
Exercise makes your muscles strong and changes your body shape. It helps you stand or sit correctly. It stops muscle problems that can cause injuries. Exercise makes your heart and lungs healthy and helps blood move in your body.
Exercise can also make you feel less sad and tired. It helps you sleep better and feel less stressed. Exercise can help with some health problems too.
There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, jogging, or lifting weights. But be careful not to train too hard. Start slowly and ask your doctor if you are unsure.
Good posture is important. It helps you look and feel better. If you slouch, imagine a balloon pulling your head up. This helps you stand tall and breathe better.
Stretching your muscles is also important. It makes you more flexible and helps prevent injuries. Stretching should be part of your exercise routine. Do it slowly and carefully.
The best exercise routine includes warming up, stretching, a good workout, and cooling down.

**In Their Natural Home**
Why do film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their comfortable homes for many months? They want to find the perfect picture. Amanda and Owen work in East Africa, in places like the Ngorongoro Crater. It rains a lot there, which makes their work hard. They bought a special tool to help when their car gets stuck in the mud. Amanda and Owen make great wildlife films for TV. They made a famous film about leopards. Now, they are filming jackals, another shy animal.
Amanda and Owen travel a lot to film animals. They have been doing this since TV started. I talked to Owen at a safari lodge. He said they sometimes argue, but they quickly make up. They do not have a leader. They both love animals and see them the same way. They sleep in tents and wake up early. They make tea the night before and keep it warm. They eat pre-packed meals. They can be away for up to eight weeks, which can be hard.
Being alone in nature helps them get close to animals. Once, a lioness treated their car like part of her family. Amanda and Owen started working together in 1988. They need four months to make enough film for a 30-minute show. They must write a plan before they start filming. Owen says they work well together because they have the same ideas. They want to make films that show the true spirit of the place and animals. They want people to feel something when they watch their films.

**The Netball Captain**
This is a story about a woman in sports. Suzie Ellis met Kendra Slawinski, the captain of England's netball team. Kendra is getting ready for the World Championships next month. She teaches at a school during the day and then trains in a supermarket car park. 
I asked Kendra if people look at her strangely when she trains there. She said she is too focused on her practice to notice. She only sees cars slowing down sometimes.
Kendra wants to be her best for the Championships. This is her fourth time at the World Championships. There will be 27 countries playing, and it will be the biggest one yet. Kendra is happy because they will have support from people in England. 
Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. England has always won against Barbados, but Kendra thinks it will be an exciting game. England is ranked fourth in the world, but the Championships will be hard. They have to play every day without rest. 
Kendra has been playing netball for 15 years. The game is now faster and harder. Players are more aggressive, but they are friendly after the game. 
Netball teams now use science to help with fitness. Kendra says it is important to think and train like the best players in the world. As captain, she wants to support and encourage her team.
Kendra has planned her netball career carefully. She decided this will be her last competition as a player. She might coach young players in the future. At the opening ceremony, she might feel emotional, but her fans will support her.

Rachel Mills is a scientist. She studies the sea and teaches at Southampton University. Rachel goes to the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean in a small steel vehicle. This vehicle is like a small car. She studies underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. Rachel can touch the two pilots. They cannot stand up or move much. They stay inside for 16 hours. It takes three hours to go down, ten hours to work, and three hours to come back up.
If there is a problem, they can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vehicle go up fast. It is like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has used it yet, but it might not be fun.
Rachel was nervous the first time she went in the vehicle. She learned what to do in an emergency. Now, she has made six dives. Last year, she went with a Russian team. They went to a place with many underwater volcanoes. The Russian team put some equipment there to study the volcanoes.
When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office. She loves teaching, but she also loves studying the "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes. They let out water that looks like black smoke. The water is very hot.
Rachel was scared once when she was with an American team. There was a loud bang, and she thought she might die. But nothing happened, and she was very happy to be safe.
Rachel loves diving in the ocean. She feels amazed when she sees the underwater volcanoes. She studied them for three years. Seeing them in real life was an amazing feeling for her.

**Interview Tips**
First impressions are very important. People decide what they think about us in the first few minutes. They look at how we dress, our eye contact, our body movement, how fast or slow we talk, and our voice. 
Mary Pearce wanted to be a teacher. She worked hard and got her degree. She was confident when she finished school. She applied for a job at a primary school and got an interview. On the day of the interview, she saw a small hole in her jacket. She did not change her jacket because she did not want to be late. Mary did not get the job. The Head Teacher thought she did not care about her appearance.
Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says people who look like they care about themselves will care about their jobs. In an interview, you should look your best. Many people forget this. 
Janet Goodwood worked as an assistant for ten years. She wanted a promotion but did not get an interview. The Director of Personnel said she did not look like a manager. He told her to dress better next time. Janet was surprised because she thought her work was more important than her clothes.
How we move and our gestures are also important in an interview. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message comes from words. 38% comes from our voice, and 55% comes from our facial expressions. If our face and words do not match, people believe our face more. Make sure your words and body language match.
Do not look too desperate for the job. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, was very excited when she got a job offer. Her boss saw her excitement and offered her a lower salary. She thinks she could have gotten more money if she stayed calm.
What we say and how we say it is important too. David Artesio, a manager, says to learn about the company before the interview. Talk about something you like about the company. This shows you are interested. Marian Woodall, a business consultant, says to have a few questions ready. Speak in short sentences, not long ones.

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**
Matt Froggatt used to work in insurance in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became boring. He lost his job suddenly. He used the money he got to start the farm. He met a chef from a famous hotel, and now he sells meat to them and by mail. He is happy not to be in an office, but he still works a lot.
**The Painter**
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. Painting was his hobby, and he liked it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. He talked to a career counselor who was surprised because most people need to work for money. Ron and his family moved to the north of England. They left their friends, but many friends visit them now.
**The Hat Maker**
Katherine Goodison was a lawyer. Now, she makes hats in her London home. She liked her job, but the hours were too long. She did not want to work more, so she left. People thought she would get bored, but she is busy with her hat business. She likes being in charge of her work. She misses talking to colleagues but enjoys being responsible for her product.
**The Masseur**
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur in London. He liked the excitement of finance but not the work. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he quit and traveled for a year. He wanted to work in health, so he learned about massage. He now works part-time as a masseur and feels happy and in control of his life.

**Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**
**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I love sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and running. When I was 14, I tried to join a professional football team, but I chose running instead. My best moment was when I ran for my country and won a medal. I hoped for more attention and sponsorship, but it didn't happen. Training is expensive. I train at home in winter and go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun there, but I must be disciplined. I can't go out with friends before training. My big goal is to go to the next Olympics.
**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing world is small, so I see the same people at competitions. Surfers are serious, and the best waves are early in the morning. So, I can't go to late-night parties.
