Carlos Dear Carlos, Hotels in the center are expensive, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria about you. She says you can all stay at her house. Her house has more bedrooms than my house! Is that okay with you? David

'Buildings People have always made buildings. We need houses to stay warm and dry. We build stadiums to watch football games and concerts. We use museums to keep beautiful things safe. Many people help to make a building. The architect plans how the building will look and draws pictures. Engineers make sure the building is strong and safe. Then, workers build it. The Sydney Opera House is a famous building with a nice roof. It looks beautiful from every side. The Olympic Stadium in Munich also has a famous roof. It looks like a glass tent.'

'Indre, I have a problem and I need your help. Can you come shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother will be 80 years old next month, and she is having a party on Saturday. The problem is I don't have anything to wear. I have grown, and all my trousers are too short now! I want to buy some new trousers and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have a lot of money, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet me in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika'

'The Cerne Giant Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England. They are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a big picture of a man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the village next to him is called Cerne. Nobody knows when the Cerne Giant was made, but it was a long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to see the picture. If you go on the first of May when the sun comes up, you will see people from the village dancing around the man on the hill.'

Gail Rollins
Gail Rollins is a very good runner from Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to run 10,000 meters and maybe 5,000 meters at the European Championships. Before, Gail often came second in big races. But she was always happy and smiling, and people in her city like her for this. 
In 2004, things changed for Gail. She ran her first half-marathon, which is a long race. She won and had the fastest time of the year for a British woman. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, also ran when he was young. But he stopped because he hurt his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes runs with Gail. But it is not fun for Mike when Gail runs faster than him.
Gail trains hard. She runs long in the morning and fast in the afternoon. But she rests on Sundays. Mike says, "I am with her all the time." Sometimes he asks, "Are you sure you should eat that?" It is usually about cakes, but Gail can eat almost everything.

**Piano Players - When They Were Young**
**Ivan Petrov**
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From age twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher couldn't play the piano but taught him and his sister opera songs. His mother started teaching him piano when he was six. At ten, he wanted to write music and began his first song.
**Oleg Gagarin**
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father taught him traditional Russian music on the piano. At six, he started piano lessons with a teacher in his city. Oleg soon won prizes for playing the piano. At fourteen, he went to a music college in Austria for two years. Later, he went back to Russia.
**Josef Heptmann**
Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two. He started playing the piano at three. He gave his first concert at six. At ten, he played fifty-two concerts in two months in England! Josef liked music, physics, and languages. He is busy now but wants to write his own music one day.

Bill Prince-Smith Bill Prince-Smith did many jobs before he started writing children's books at 60 years old. He was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist. Now, 13 years later, he has written more than 80 books. Every day, he writes in his office. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. 'She tells me when she doesn't like something,' says Bill. His ten grandchildren do not live close, but they also read his stories and say if they are good or bad. This helps Bill know what young children like to read. Bill writes about life in his village and the farms nearby. His favorite book is his fifth one: The Sheepdog. It is about a farmer and his dog. 'I have always liked animals,' says Bill, 'and dogs are very smart. They learn fast.' Last year, The Sheepdog became a film with real animals and actors. The film-makers used new computer technology to make it look like the animals are talking. Bill was very happy with the film. 'Sometimes film-makers change books, but they didn't change mine, and I love the film,' he says.

'POSTCARDS Today, people like to send postcards to their friends and family. Postcards have pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles. You can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards when they are on holiday. Postcards are cheap, and the pictures are often better than people's own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the 1800s. It had a picture of a town by the sea. Later, postcards showed pictures of news events, like an accident or an important person's visit. People liked these because newspapers did not have pictures then.'

'Dinosaurs No one has ever seen a dinosaur. Dinosaurs died about 60 million years ago, long before people lived on Earth. We do not know why they all died. Birds are the closest living relatives to dinosaurs. Dinosaurs did not all look the same. There were more than 5000 kinds. Some were very small, but others were very big. The biggest dinosaurs were the largest animals to live on land. The Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as big, but it was very strong. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast because it had long back legs.'

'BEARS Bears can be dangerous animals. Big bears are very strong and can hurt people. Bears can climb trees and run fast. But they do not see well. They use their noses to find food. There are seven kinds of bears. The biggest is the white polar bear. It is almost three meters tall. There are two kinds of black bears. One lives in North America, and the other lives in South-East Asia. Not all black bears are black. They can be dark brown or reddish brown. Many people love the black and white panda bear from China. Today, not many pandas live in the forest because it is hard to find food.'

CROCODILES
Crocodiles live in warm places in the world, like Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They like to stay in slow water, but they can move fast in water and on land. You can see many crocodiles together in big groups. They eat many things they catch, like fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they eat big animals or even people. There are more than ten kinds of crocodiles. All crocodiles have very sharp teeth. They often lose their teeth, but they grow new ones. Crocodiles are usually about 3.5 meters long, but some are much bigger. Crocodiles can live for a long time. The oldest crocodile in a zoo was 66 years old.

'A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL In 1783, two French brothers made the first balloon to carry people into the sky. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers made the first plane with an engine and flew it. This happened in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Aeroplanes changed a lot in the next thirty years. In the 1950s, planes became much faster because they had jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was made in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world and can fly at 2500 kilometres an hour, so the trip from London to New York takes only four hours. Today, millions of people travel by plane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.'

'The Globe Theatre Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from today. The building was round and had no roof, so people got cold and wet if it rained. The queen liked going to the Globe Theatre by the River Thames to watch plays by William Shakespeare. All the actors were men. People in the audience ate, talked, walked around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same place near the river. You can watch a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the 1600s.'

This week we are in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water is warm, and I love swimming there. The fish are different colors: red, yellow, purple!
